No award made under this Ordinance shall be chargeable with stamp duty, and no person claiming any interest under any such award shall be liable to pay any fee for a copy of the same.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Indemnity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">43. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against any person for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Ordinance or any order or rule made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Bar to jurisdiction of Court</p><p style="text-align: justify;">44. Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Ordinance, no Court shall entertain any suit or application against any order passed or any action taken under this Ordinance, and no injunction shall be granted by any Court in respect of any action taken or to be taken in pursuance of any power conferred by or under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Delegation of powers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">45. The Government may, by order notified in the official Gazette, direct that any power conferred or any duty imposed on it by this Ordinance shall, in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercised or discharged also by such officer or authority as may be so specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">46. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the procedure to be followed in taking possession of any property acquired or requisitioned under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the procedure to be followed by the Arbitrators and the Arbitration Appellate Tribunals;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the manner of enforcement of surrender of any property under section 41;</p><p></p></div><div class="popular-posts widget widget_categories"><h3 class="widget-title"><span>Disclaimer:</span></h3><div class="widget-content" style="text-align:justify;"><p>The information contains in this web-site is prepared for educational purpose. 606	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE AGRICULTURAL LABOUR (MINIMUM WAGES) ORDINANCE 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE AGRICULTURAL LABOUR (MINIMUM WAGES) ORDINANCE 1984</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XVII OF 1984).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[22nd February, 1984]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for fixation of minimum rates of wages for agricultural labourers. WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for fixation of minimum rates of wages for agricultural labourers and for matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Agricultural Labour (Minimum Wages) Ordinance 1984.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “agricultural labourer” means any person employed in agricultural crop production, but does not include-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         a person employed by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        a person employed in a plantation as defined in clause (iii) of section 2 of the Payment of Wages Act, 1936 (IV of 1936);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       a person who works as a family labourer on monthly wages;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       a person employed by a company registered under the Companies Act, 1913 (VII of 1913), engaged in production and sale of fish or livestock of any kind;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(v)        a bargadar as defined in the Land Reforms Ordinance 1984 (X of 1984);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)       “wages” means all remuneration which would, if the terms of contract of employment, express or implied, were fulfilled, be payable to a person in respect of his employment or work done in such employment, but does not include any sum paid to such person to defray special expenses incurred by him in respect of his employment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Minimum wages for agricultural labour</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The minimum rate of wages for agricultural labour per day shall be 3.27 kilograms of rice or such amount of money as is equal to the price of this quantity of rice in the local market.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, review from time to time the minimum rate of wages fixed under sub-section (1), on the recommendation of the Council of Minimum Wages and Prices for Agricultural Labour constituted under section 4.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may, on review of the minimum rate of wages under sub-section (2), fix different rates of minimum wages for different areas, for different classes of agricultural labourer or different kinds of agricultural labourer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Notwithstanding anything contained in this section, no rate of minimum wages shall be reviewed earlier than three years from the date on which it was fixed, unless special circumstances so require.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Constitution of Council of Minimum Wages and Prices for Agricultural Labour</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, constitute a Council to be called the Council of Minimum Wages and Prices for Agricultural Labour for the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Council shall consist of a Chairman and such number of other members as the Government may deem fit to appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Council shall, upon a reference made to it by the Government, recommend to the Government, after such enquiry as the Council thinks fit and after consideration of the economic conditions, costs of living and other relevant factors, the minimum rates of wages for agricultural labour.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Council may, if the circumstances so demand, recommend different rates of minimum wages for different areas, for different classes of agricultural labourer or for different kinds of agricultural labour.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) In making its recommendations, the Council shall take into consideration the views of the Upazila Parishads, if any.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Payment of minimum wages</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) No person shall pay any agricultural labourer wages at a rate lower than the rate fixed by or under this Ordinance to be the minimum wages for such labourer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to affect, in any way, the right of an agricultural labourer to continue to receive wages at a rate higher than the minimum rate fixed by or under this Ordinance, if under any agreement or contract or otherwise, he is entitled to receive wages at such higher rate, or to continue to enjoy such amenities and other advantages as are customary for such labourer to enjoy.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Compensation and recovery procedure</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) Any person who contravenes the provision of section 5 shall be liable to pay to the aggrieved person compensation of an amount not exceeding two times the amount which would have been paid to him had there been no such contravention.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, a suit for recovery of the wages and compensation payable to an agricultural labourer shall lie to a Village Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Protection of minimum wage</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The minimum rates of wages fixed by or under this Ordinance shall not be called in question in or before any Court or authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Amendment of Ordinance LXI of 1976</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. In the Village Courts Ordinance, 1976 (LXI of 1976), in the Schedule, in Part II, after item 5, the following new item shall be added, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">“6. Suit for recovery of wages and compensation payable to agricultural labourers.”</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
607	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE APPROPRIATION ACT, 1981</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE APPROPRIATION ACT, 1981</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ACT NO. XII OF 1981).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[30th June, 1981]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to authorise payment and appropriation of certain sums from and out of the Consolidated Fund for the services of the financial year ending on the thirtieth day of June, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to authorise payment and appropriation of certain sums from and out of the Consolidated Fund for the services of the financial year ending on the thirtieth day of the June, 1982;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. 611	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE ATTIA FOREST (PROTECTION) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE ATTIA FOREST (PROTECTION) ORDINANCE, 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXIII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[11th September, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make provision for the protection of the Attia Forest in the districts of Dacca and Tangail.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provisions for the protection of the Attia  Forest in the districts of Dacca and Tangail;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Attia  Forest (Protection) Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definition</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context, “Court” means a civil, criminal or revenue Court and includes the High Court Division and the Appellate Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Constitution of reserved forest</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Notwithstanding anything contained to the contrary in the Forest Act, 1927 (XVI of 1927), or in any other law for the time being in force, or in any judgment, decree or order, the lands comprising of 59,648.70 acres constituting a reserved forest known as the Attia Forest under Notifications mentioned in the Schedule shall, notwithstanding any defect in such constitution or Notifications, be deemed to have been validly constituted a reserved forest and the Notifications so issued shall be deemed to have had effect accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Abatement of legal proceedings</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The constitution of Reserved forest as is referred to in section 3 shall not be called in question on any ground whatsoever before any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All suits, appeals, petitions, applications, and other legal proceedings pending immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance in any Court against the Government or any of its officers in which the constitution of the reserved forest or the Notification as are referred to in section 3 has been called in questions in any manner whatsoever shall abate forthwith and shall not be further proceeded with.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
612	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH CONSUMER SUPPLIES CORPORATION (REPEAL) ACT, 1981</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH CONSUMER SUPPLIES CORPORATION (REPEAL) ACT, 1981</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ACT NO. III OF 1981).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[30th April, 1981]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Act to repeal the Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation Order 1972.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal the Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation Order 1972 (P.O. No. 47 of 1972), and to provide for matters connected with such repeal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">It is hereby enacted as follows:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>commencement:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Act may be called the Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation (Repeal) Act 1981.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 25th day of March, 1981.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal of PO No 47 of 1972</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation Order, 1972 (P.O. No. 47 of 1972), hereinafter referred to as the said Order, is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Savings:</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Notwithstanding the repeal of the said Order and anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract or legal instrument, upon such repeal-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) all assets and liabilities of the Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation established by the said Order, hereinafter referred to as the said Corporation, shall, in accordance with such arrangement as the Government may determine, stand transferred to the Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Company Limited, hereinafter referred to as the Company;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation:</strong> The expression “assets” includes all rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all property, movable and immovable, including lands, buildings, works, vehicles, cash balance, reserve funds, bank deposits, investments and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such property and all books of accounts, registers, records and all other documents of whatever nature relating thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said Corporation shall be deemed to have been instituted by or against the Company and may be continued or proceeded with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all Officers and other employees of the said Corporation shall stand transferred to the Company and shall hold office or service in the Company on such terms and conditions as the Company may determine:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that an Officer or other employee so transferred shall have the option not to continue in the service of the Company.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal and savings</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Bangladesh Consumer Supplies Corporation (Repeal) Ordinance, 1981 (Ord. IV of 1981), is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding such repeal, anything done or any action taken or any order made under the said Ordinance shall be deemed to have been done, taken or made, as the case may be, under the corresponding provision of this Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
613	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH FLAG VESSELS (PROTECTION) ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH FLAG VESSELS (PROTECTION) ORDINANCE 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XIV OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[28th June, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide protection for the Bangladesh f lag vessels.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide protection for the Bangladesh f lag vessels;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title and commencement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Flag Vessels (Protection) Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Bangladesh flag vessel” means a vessel registered in Bangladesh; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Prescribed Authority” means the Director-General, Department of Shipping, Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, or any other officer, body or authority appointed by the Government as such.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Limitation on carriage of cargoes of sea-borne trade</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, at least forty per cent of the sea-borne cargoes relating to foreign trade of Bangladesh shall, subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance, be carried by Bangladesh f lag vessels:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that this limitation shall not apply to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        any cargo which is required to be carried by any vessel in accordance with any reciprocal arrangement made between the two trading partners; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        any cargo in respect of which a certificate of waiver is issued by the Prescribed Authority 1[ ; or]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2[ (c) any cargo in respect of which a general waiver is announced by the Prescribed Authority.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Carriage of cargoes by third country f lag vessels</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Where there is no Bangladesh flag vessel or flag vessel of the trading country concerned available for carriage of any cargo from or to Bangladesh, the Prescribed Authority may liberate the cargo for carriage by a third country f lag vessel.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where the country to which or from which any cargo is to be carried is not served by Bangladesh f lag vessels and the f lag vessels of that country also do not serve Bangladesh, the Prescribed Authority may liberate the cargo for carriage by a third country f lag vessel.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Non-Bangladesh Flag vessels not to carry coastal trade cargoes</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. No f lag vessel of any foreign country shall carry coastal trade cargoes of Bangladesh:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that this restriction shall not apply to a vessel in respect of which a certificate of waiver is issued by the Prescribed Authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition to join liner conference without licence</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. No owner of Bangladesh f lag vessels shall join or form a liner conference without obtaining a licence from the Prescribed Authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Grant of licence, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) An Application for a licence under section 6 shall be made in such manner and in such form, and shall be accompanied by such fee, as the Government may specify in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any person aggrieved by refusal of a licence under section 6 may prefer an appeal, within three days from the date of such refusal, to the Government whose decision in the matter shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalty</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) If any vessel carries any cargo in contravention of any provision of this Ordinance, the owner of the vessel shall be punishable with fine not exceeding the value of the freight of such cargo.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes any provision of this Ordinance not punishable under sub-section (1) shall be punishable with fine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Offences by companies</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) If the person contravening any of the provisions of this Ordinance is a company, every person who at the time the offence was committed, was in charge of and was responsible to, the company for the conduct of the business of the company as well as the company shall be deemed to be guilty of the contravention and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing contained in this sub-section shall render any such person liable to any punishment provided in this Ordinance if he proves that the offence was committed without his knowledge or that he exercised all due diligence to prevent the commission of such offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where any offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company and it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other officer of the company, such director, manager, secretary or other officer shall also be deemed to be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.- For the purposes of this section,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “company” means any body corporate and includes a firm or other association of individuals, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “director”, in relation to a firm, means a partner in the firm.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The semi-colon (;) was substituted for the full-stop (.) and thereafter the word “or” was added by section 2 of the Bangladesh Flag Vessels (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVI of 2003)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 Clause (c) was substituted by section 2 of The Bangladesh Flag Vessels (Protection) (Amendment) Act, 2009 (Act. No. XVIII of 2009) (with effect from 12th July, 2007).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
614	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH HOMOEOPATHIC PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH HOMOEOPATHIC PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE, 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XLI OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[25th August, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the regulation of the qualifications and registration of practitioners of Homoeopathic system of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the regulation of the qualifications and registration of practitioners of Homoeopathic system of medicine and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER I</p><p style="text-align: justify;">PRELIMINARY</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Homoeopathic Practitioners Ordinance, 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Board” means the Bangladesh Homoeopathic Board established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “Homoeopath” means a practitioner of Homoeopathic system of medicine and includes a practitioner of Biochemic system of medicine founded by Dr. Schuessler;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “Homoeopathy” means the system of medicine founded by Dr. Samuel Hahnemann;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “List” means the list of Homoeopaths maintained under section 27;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “member” means a member of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        “prescribed” means prescribed by rules or regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        “recognised” means recognised by the Government for the purpose of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         “register” means a register of practitioners of Homoeopathic or Bio-chemic system of medicine maintained under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         “registered practitioner” means a practitioner of Homoeopathic or Biochemic system of medicine whose name is for the time being entered in a register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        “Registrar” means the Registrar of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         “regulations” means regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) “rules” means rules made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) “teacher” means a person appointed, with the approval of the Board, to teach in a recognised Homoeopathic institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Establishment and incorporation of Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, establish a Board to be called the Bangladesh Board of Homoeopathic system of Medicine for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall be a body corporate, having perpetual succession and a common seal, with power to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER II</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CONSTITUTION AND FUNCTIONS OF THE BOARD</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Composition of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Board shall consist of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a Chairman to be nominated by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        one member from each administrative division to be elected by the teachers of recognised teaching institutions of Homoeopathy of the division concerned from amongst themselves;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        one member from each administrative division to be nominated by the Government from amongst the registered practitioners of Homoeopathy and listed Homoeopaths;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) two women members to be nominated by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The members under sub section (1)(b) shall be elected in such manner as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub section (1), for the purpose of constituting the Board for the first time, the members required to be elected under sub section (1)(b) shall be nominated by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Terms of office of Chairman and members</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The Chairman and a member of the Board shall, subject to other provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder, hold office for a term of three years from the date of his election or nomination as Chairman or member, as the case may be, or until his successor shall have been duly elected or nominated, whichever period is longer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A member elected under section 4(1)(b) shall be deemed to have vacated his seat if he ceases to be teacher of any teaching institution of Homoeopathy.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A casual vacancy in the Board shall be filled by election or nomination, as the case may be, and the person elected or nominated to fill the vacancy shall hold office only for the remainder of the term for which the member whose place he takes was elected or nominated.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where the said term of three years is about to expire in respect of any member or members, a successor or successors may be elected or nominated, as the case may be, at any time within three months before the said term expires but the member or members so elected or nominated shall not assume office until the said term has expired.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Publication of names, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Government shall publish in the official Gazette the names of the Chairman and the members of the Board together with the dates on which such members are elected or nominated.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Vacancies not to invalidate proceedings of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. No act or proceedings of the Board shall be invalid merely on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the composition of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Resignation from membership</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. The Chairman may resign his office by letter addressed to the Government and a member may resign his office by letter addressed to the Chairman and such resignation shall take effect from the date it is accepted by the Government or the Chairman, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power of Government to nominate members in certain circumstances</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. If the electors referred to in section 4(1)(b) fail to elect a member within the prescribed period, the Government shall fill up the office of such member by nomination of a person qualified to be elected by such electors; and any person so nominated by the Government shall be deemed to have been duly elected by such electors.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Declaration of vacancies</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. If any member-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        dies; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        absents himself, without such reasons as may in the opinion of the Board be sufficient, from three consecutive ordinary meetings of the Board; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in section 11;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Board shall declare his office vacant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Disqualification of members</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. No person shall be a member of the Board, if-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        he is not a citizen of Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        he is an undischarged insolvent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        he has been adjudicated by a competent Court to be of unsound mind;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        he has at any time been convicted of an offence which in the opinion of the Government involves moral turpitude;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        he has been dismissed from the service of the Government or a local authority on a charge of gross misconduct or an offence involving moral turpitude; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         he is less than 25 years of age.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Control over the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. If, in the opinion of the Government, anything done or intended to be done by or on behalf of the Board is not in conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance or is in any way against public interest, the Government may, by order,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        quash the proceedings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        suspend the execution of any resolution passed or order made by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        prohibit the doing of anything proposed to be done; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        require the Board to take such action as may be specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Functions of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. The following shall be the functions of the Board, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to consider applications for recognition under this Ordinance made by institutions imparting or desiring to impart instruction in Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to ensure the maintenance of an adequate standard of efficiency in recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        to appoint committees and sub-committees for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        to regulate academic and teaching standard of Homoeopathy and to upgrade the professional practice thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        to hold seminars and arrange for refresher courses on Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         to arrange, from time to time, for short courses of study for upgrading the standard of the registered Homoeopaths and to grant certificates to those attending the courses on passing the examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        to hold examinations and confer certificates, diplomas and degrees in Homoeopathic medicine and surgery;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        to make arrangement for the registration of duly qualified persons in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         to provide for research in Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         to arrange for the writing of text-books on Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        to publish journals, bulletins and other literatures on Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         to grant scholarships, stipends, prizes and medals to meritorious and deserving students of recognised institutions and to arrange research or special study on Homoeopathy by students of recognised institutions in Bangladesh or abroad;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       to supervise the arrangements made by the recognised institutions in respect of residence, health and general welfare of their students;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        to establish, manage and control Homoeopathic colleges, hospitals and charitable dispensaries and sanction grants to charitable Homoeopathic dispensaries;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o)        to establish and manage a Homoeopathic medical store for supplying medicines and other accessories to the Homoeopathic hospitals and dispensaries attached to the recognised Homoeopathic medical colleges and to Homoeopathic hospital and dispensaries established and managed by it or on private initiative;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p)        to prepare Bangladesh Homoeopathic Pharmacopoeia on the basis of principles of Homoeopathy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q)        to do such other acts and things as it may be empowered or required to do by this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Meetings of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Board shall meet at such time and place, and every meeting of the Board shall be summoned in such manner, as may be prescribed by regulations:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, until such regulations are made, the Chairman may, by notice addressed to each member, summon a meeting of the Board at such time and place as he may deem expedient.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Chairman shall preside at every meeting of the Board, and in his absence, the members present shall elect a member from amongst themselves to preside.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Except as hereinafter provided, all questions at a meeting of the Board shall be decided by majority of the votes of the members present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) At a meeting of the Board four members shall form a quorum.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) At every meeting of the Board, the Chairman for the time being shall, in addition to his vote as a member of the Board, have a second or casting vote in case of an equality of votes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Officers of the Board and their terms and conditions of service</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) The Board shall, with the previous approval in writing of the Government, appoint a Registrar on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the office of the Registrar is vacant or if the Registrar is unable to perform functions of his office on account of absence, illness or any other cause, the Board may, with the previous approval of the Government, appoint any officer of the Board to act as Registrar until a new Registrar is appointed or until the Registrar resumes the functions of his office, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board may appoint such other employees as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Registrar shall be the Secretary to the Board and shall exercise such powers and perform such duties as may be prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Registrar may, in the event of an urgency, appoint for the efficient performance of the functions of the Board, such employees as he considers necessary on the terms and conditions prescribed by regulations:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that every appointment under this sub-section shall be reported to the Board forthwith and no such appointment shall continue beyond six months unless approved by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER III</p><p style="text-align: justify;">TEACHING INSTITUTIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Recognition of institutions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) Any institution imparting or desiring to impart instruction in the Homoeopathic system of medicine may apply for recognition under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An application for recognition shall be addressed to the Registrar and shall contain full information in respect of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the constitution and personnel of the managing body of the institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the subjects and courses in which it imparts or proposes to impart instruction as per syllabi and curriculum of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the number of beds in the attached hospital;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the equipment possessed by the institution and the number of students for whom accommodation and other provision have been made or are proposed to be made;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        the facilities provided or proposed to be provided for dissection and study of subjects, such as, Biology, Anatomy, Physiology and Pathology;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         the strength and particulars of the staff, their salaries, qualifications and the research work to their credit;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        the fees levied or proposed to be levied and the provisions made for capital expenditure on buildings and equipment and for the continued maintenance and efficient working of the institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        the permanent assets and the reserve fund in the name of the institution in bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Registrar shall place the application before the Board, and the Board may direct the Registrar to call for any further information which it may consider necessary, and may also direct a local inquiry to be made by competent person or persons authorised by it in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) After considering the report of such local inquiry, if any, and making such further inquiry as may appear to it to be necessary, the Board shall, subject to the approval of the Government, grant or refuse to grant recognition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) When recognition is granted to an institution under this section, the name of the institution shall be published by the Board in the official Gazette.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Recognised Homoeopathic Institutions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Homoeopathic institutions specified in the Schedule shall be recognised Homoeopathic institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board may, with the approval of the Government, by notification in the official Gazette, include any foreign Homoeopathic institution in Part ‘B' of the Schedule.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Maintenance of standard of efficiency</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) It shall be the duty of the Board to secure the maintenance of an adequate standard of efficiency in recognised institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) For the purpose of securing such standard, the Board may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) from time to time call upon any recognised institution to furnish such particulars as the Board may require of any course of study provided or examination conducted by such institution; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) depute inspectors or teachers of recognised Homoeopathic institutions to attend and be present at all or any of the examinations conducted by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The inspectors or teachers shall not interfere with the conduct of any examination and their duty shall be to report to the Board their opinion as to the sufficiency or otherwise of an examination which they attend, and any other matter in relation to such examination on which the Board may require them to report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Board shall arrange periodical inspection of recognised institutions and supervision of examinations conducted by the Board through inspectors, to be appointed by the Board, and shall pay such salaries and allowances and travelling expenses to the inspectors as may be fixed by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Withdrawal of recognition</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The Board when it thinks fit may, and when required to do so by the Government shall, make an inquiry whether any recognised institution should cease to be a recognised institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If, in making such an inquiry, and after considering all such information and reports as are referred to in the preceding section and making such further inquiry as may appear to it to be necessary, the Board is satisfied that the courses of study provided or the examinations conducted by a recognised institution are not such as to secure an adequate standard of efficiency for the practice of Homoeopathy, it shall make an order withdrawing the recognition:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no order under this sub-section shall be made unless the institution concerned has been given an opportunity to raise, within a specified time, the standard of the courses of study and examination to the satisfaction of the Board, and the institution has, in the opinion of the Board, failed to do so.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Duration of courses</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) The duration of diploma course in a recognised institution of Homoeopathy shall be four years with internship for an additional period of six months.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board may arrange for degree and other higher courses in Homoeopathy and the duration and subjects of such courses shall be as prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Qualification for admission</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. The minimum qualifications required for admission to different courses shall be as prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Qualifying examination</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. (1) A qualifying examination shall be held at least once in every year for the purpose of granting diploma or degree conferring the right of registration under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The examination shall be held on the subjects prescribed by regulations and the right of appearing at the examination shall be restricted to candidates who have undergone a course of study in such subjects in the prescribed manner at a recognised institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Examining body</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. The examination shall be held under the control of an examining body to be appointed by the Board duly approved by the Government on annual basis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Controller of Examinations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. The Board may, with the approval of the Government, appoint a Controller of Examinations who shall act as Secretary to the examining body and so long as the Controller of Examinations is not appointed, the Registrar shall perform the functions of the Controller of Examinations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER IV</p><p style="text-align: justify;">REGISTRATION OF PRACTITIONERS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Procedure of registration</p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. (1) Application for registration under this Ordinance shall be made in such form and on payment of such fee as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Applications under section 26(1) shall be received annually after the results of the examinations held under section 23 are declared.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board shall examine the applications received under this section and after making such inquires as it thinks fit regarding the qualifications and the length and nature of practice of the applicants and their professional efficiency direct the entry of the names of eligible applicants to be made in the register in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registration of practitioners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. (1) Every person who passes the qualifying examination in the Homoeopathic system of medicine from any of the institutions mentioned in the Schedule may apply under section 25.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every person who is a registered medical practitioner within the meaning of the Medical and Dental Council Act, 1980 (XVI of 1980), and passed a written examination on the subjects of Homoeopathic Materia Medica, Principles of Homoeopathy and practice of medicine and Homoeopathic Philosophy to be conducted by the examining body appointed under section 23, may apply under section 25.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Listing of certain Homoeopaths</p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. (1) The Registrar shall prepare and maintain a list of Homoeopaths who are entitled to have their names to be entered therein under sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every person who has applied to the Board before the commencement of this Ordinance and proves to the satisfaction of the Board that he has not less than five years practice to his credit and has the requisite knowledge and skill for the efficient practice of Homoeopathy, shall on payment of such fees as may be prescribed by rules be entitled to have his name entered in the list maintained under sub section (1):</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that a person who has applied under this sub-section shall be entitled to practise Homoeopathy until his application is disposed of.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Every person whose name has been entered in the list maintained under this section shall be entitled to the privilege specified in section 33(b).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Removal from register, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. The Board may direct that the name of any practitioner who has been convicted of a cognizable offence or who after the enquiry has been found guilty of misconduct shall be removed from the register or the list, as the case may be, if the offence or misconduct, in the opinion of the Board, discloses moral turpitude such as to render him unfit to practise his profession:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no action shall be taken by the Board under this section unless the person convicted of the cognizable offence or found guilty of misconduct has been given a reasonable opportunity to show cause against the punishment proposed to be inflicted on him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cancellation or alteration of entries in register, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. The Board may, on its own motion or on information received from any person and after due enquiry and giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard, cancel or alter any entry in the register or the list, as the case may be, if in the opinion of the Board the entry was made fraudulently or improperly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER V</p><p style="text-align: justify;">POWERS AND DUTIES OF REGISTRAR</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Maintenance of register, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. (1) Subject to any general or special orders of the Board, it shall be the duty of the Registrar to keep the register and the list and to attend the meetings of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The register and the list shall contain the name, present and permanent addresses and qualifications of every practitioner registered or listed under this Ordinance and the date on which the qualifications were acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Registrar shall keep the register and the list correct and up to date and shall, from time to time, enter therein any alteration in the present and permanent addresses and qualifications of the practitioners, and remove therefrom the names of the practitioners who die or whose names are directed to be removed in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government may by rules prescribe any fee for any alteration in the register due to additional qualifications and for re-entry in the register under sub-section (5).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) If the Registrar has reason to believe that any registered or listed practitioner has ceased to practise or has changed his present or permanent address without due information to him, he may write, by registered post, to such practitioner at the address as entered in the register or the list, as the case may be, to inquire whether he has ceased to practise or has changed his present or permanent address or residence, and if within six months no reply is received, the Registrar may remove the name of such practitioner from the register or the list, as the case may be:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Board may, at any time on the application of the practitioner whose name is removed under this sub-section, order that the name of such practitioner be re-entered in the register or the list, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Publication of list</p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. (1) The Registrar shall, in every fifth years, on or before a date to be fixed by the Board cause to be published a correct list of the names and qualifications, for the time being entered in the register and list and the dates when such qualifications were acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall be presumed that any person whose name has been entered in any such list, is a registered or a listed practitioner, as the case may be, and that any person whose name is not so entered is neither a registered nor a listed practitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER VI</p><p style="text-align: justify;">RIGHTS, DUTIES AND LIABILITIES OF REGISTERED PRACTITIONERS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Intimation of change of address</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. Every registered practitioner shall inform the Registrar of any change in his permanent address.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Privileges of registered practitioners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">33. Notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force, every practitioner registered under section 26(1) shall be entitled-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to hold any appointment as a teacher, physician or medical officer in any Homoeopathic medical college, dispensary, hospital, infirmary or lying in hospital if such dispensary, hospital, infirmary or lying in hospital is supported by, or receives a grant from, the Government or any local authority and treats patients according to Homoeopathic system of medicine or in any public establishment, body or institution practising such system; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to recover fees through Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Code of Ethics</p><p style="text-align: justify;">34. A registered practitioner and listed Homoeopath shall abide by the Code of Ethics for Homoeopathic practitioners framed by the Board and approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER VII</p><p style="text-align: justify;">RESTRICTIONS, OFFENCES, PENALTY AND PROCEDURE</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Restrictions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">35. No practitioner registered under section 26 or, as the case may be, entered in the list under section 27 shall stock, prescribe or sell any drugs or medicines except such as are included in the Homoeopathic Pharmacopoeia approved by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">36. Whoever contravenes the provisions of section 34 or 35, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Persons not registered under this Ordinance not to practise, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">37. (1) No person other than a practitioner registered or listed under this Ordinance shall practise or hold himself out, whether directly or by implication, as practising the Homoeopathic system of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes the provisions of this section shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Colourable imitation of degree</p><p style="text-align: justify;">38. (1) No person other than a body or institution authorised under this Ordinance shall confer, grant or issue a degree, diploma or certificate which purports to entitle the holder to practise Homoeopathic system of medicine, or which is identical with or is a colourable imitation of any degree, diploma or certificate granted by a body or institution so authorised.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes the provisions of this section shall be punishable with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, and if the person so contravening is an association, every member of such association, who knowingly or wilfully authorises or permits the contravention, shall be punishable with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition against use of title, description, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">39. (1) No person shall add to his name, title or description any letters or abbreviation which imply or are calculated to lead to the belief that he holds a degree, diploma or certificate as his</p><p style="text-align: justify;">qualification to practise the Homoeopathic system of medicine unless he holds such degree, diploma or certificate and such degree, diploma or certificate-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        is recognised by any law for the time being in force in Bangladesh; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        has been conferred, granted or issued by a body or institution authorised under this Ordinance in this behalf; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) has been conferred, granted or issued by an authority recognised as competent by the Government to confer, grant or issue such degree, diploma or certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes the provisions of this section shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Savings</p><p style="text-align: justify;">40. Nothing in this Chapter shall apply to any person who, being a technical assistant attends on a case under the direction and personal guidance of registered practitioners of Homoeopathy.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cognizance of offence, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">41. (1) No Court shall take cognizance of any offence under this Ordinance except on a complaint in writing by an officer empowered in this behalf by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No Court other than the Court of a Magistrate of the first class shall try an offence under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER VIII</p><p style="text-align: justify;">SUPERSESSION OF THE BOARD</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Supersession of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">42. (1) If at any time it appears to the Government that the Board has failed to exercise or has exceeded or abused any of the powers conferred upon it by or under this Ordinance, or has failed to perform a duty imposed upon it by this Ordinance, the Government may, if it considers such failure, excess or abuse to be of a serious character, notify the particulars thereof to the Board, and if the Board fails to remedy such failures, excess or abuse, within such time as may be fixed in this behalf, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, supersede the Board for such period not exceeding ninety days, as may be specified in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the supersession of the Board under sub section (1),-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the persons holding office as Chairman and members of the Board shall cease to hold office; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all powers and functions of the Board shall, during the period of supersession, be exercised and performed by such person or authority as the Government may appoint in this behalf, as if such person or authority were the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board shall be reconstituted in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance for the exercise and performance of its powers and functions on the expiry of the period specified in the notification under sub section (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER IX</p><p style="text-align: justify;">MISCELLANEOUS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Grants, aids, fees, etc, received by the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">43. All moneys received by the Board including grants, aids and fees shall be applied for the purposes of the Board in accordance with the rules and regulations made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Death of a registered or listed practitioner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">44. Every person in charge of registration of deaths shall, on receiving notice of the death of a registered or listed practitioner, forthwith transmit by post to the Registrar a certificate under his own hand of such death with the particulars of time and place of death and may charge from the Registrar the cost of such certificate and transmission as an expense of his office.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Indemnity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">45. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any person for anything which is done or intended to be done, in good faith, under this Ordinance or the rules or regulations made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">CHAPTER X</p><p style="text-align: justify;">RULES AND REGULATIONS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">46. (1) The Government may, after consulting the Board, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules to carry out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the time and place at which and the manner in which elections shall be held;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the manner in which vacancies shall be filled;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the form of the list and register and the particulars to be entered therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        fees chargeable for enrolment of students, the registration and renewal of registration, alteration in the register regarding additional qualifications, re-entry of names and alteration of other entries in the register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the purposes of which the fees received by the Board shall be supplied;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) any other matter which may be or is required to be prescribed by rules under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make regulations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">47. The Board may, with the previous approval in writing of the Government, make regulations not inconsistent with this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder for the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) courses of study for training and qualifying examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) languages in which examination shall be conducted and instruction given;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) admission of students to recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) conditions under which candidates shall be admitted to different courses and to the qualifying and other examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the conditions for the appointment of teachers in recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) requirements for recognition of teaching institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) time and place at which the Board shall hold its meetings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) title, degree, diploma and certificate which the Board shall confer or grant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) such other matters as may be necessary for the exercise of powers and performance of functions by the Board under this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal and savings</p><p style="text-align: justify;">48. (1) The Unani, Ayurvedic and Homoeopathic Practitioners Act, 1965 (II of 1965), hereinafter referred to as the said Act, shall in so far as it relates to the Board of Homoeopathic System of Medicine established thereunder referred to as the defunct Board, is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the repeal of the said Act,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges, and all properties movable and immovable, cash and bank balances, funds of the defunct Board in Bangladesh and all other interests and rights in, or arising out of such property shall stand transferred to, and vested in the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all debts, liabilities and obligations of the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall be the debts, liabilities and obligations of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall be deemed to have been instituted by or against the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all officers and employees of the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or agreement or in the terms and conditions of service stand transferred to the Board and shall be deemed to be officers and other employees of the Board appointed by it on the same terms and conditions of service as were applicable to them in the defunct Board unless such terms and conditions are altered, not being to their disadvantage, by the Board; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) every Homoeopathic practitioner registered or listed under the said Act, shall be deemed to be registered or listed, as the case may be, under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
615	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH HOTELS AND RESTAURANTS ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH HOTELS AND RESTAURANTS ORDINANCE 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. LII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[12th December 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide measures for controlling and regulating the standards of service and amenities in hotels and restaurants.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide measures for controlling and regulating the standards of service and amenities in hotels and restaurants and for matters ancillary thereto or connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title and commencement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Hotels and Restaurants Ordinance 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)“apprentice” means any person who has contracted with a hotel or restaurant to perform the stipulated apprenticeship in such hotel or restaurant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)“Committee” means the Hotels and Restaurants Advisory Committee constituted under section 4;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)“Controller” means a Controller appointed under section 3 and includes a Deputy Controller and Assistant Controller and such other person as may be authorised by the Government, by notification in the official Gazette, to exercise and perform all or any of the powers and functions of the Controller;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)“customer” means a person availing facilities offered in a hotel or restaurant on monetary consideration;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)“fair rates” means the rates fixed under section 10;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)“guest” means a person who is in possession or enjoyment of accommodation provided to him in a hotel on monetary consideration and includes a tourist.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">In this clause, the word “tourist” means a person travelling for more than twenty four hours but less than six months in a country other than that of his normal residence but shall not include a person arriving to take up an office, occupation or engagement for gain;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)“Hotel” means a lodging, or boarding and lodging, establishment with a minimum of ten settable bed rooms, provided for guests on monetary consideration, which conforms to any of the prescribed minimum criteria, but does not include-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) a home or hostel which is exclusively or mainly used for the aged or invalid persons or students and is run by, or under the control of, a charitable or educational institution; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) any rest house, hostel or circuit house exclusively meant for visiting Government officials or officials of other organisations, though run on a commercial basis;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)“manager” means the person in charge of the management of a hotel or restaurant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) “owner” means the person who holds title to a hotel or restaurant and is entitled to receive the whole or any part of the earnings received from a guest or customer on account of accommodation or services provided in the hotel or restaurant, and includes a keeper or assignee for the time being discharging the responsibility of the owner in respect of such hotel or restaurant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) “public rooms” means rooms in a hotel which are meant for the common use of all guests and customers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)“restaurant” means a public eating house providing standard and variety of cuisines on monetary consideration to customers which conforms to the minimum prescribed criteria having seating arrangements for thirty persons and above;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(M) “service” means any service provided in a hotel or restaurant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appointment of Controller, Deputy Controllers and Assistant Controllers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint a person to be the Controller for the purpose of this Ordinance and such number of Deputy Controllers and Assistant Controllers as may be necessary for the performance and discharge of such functions and duties as may be assigned to them by or under this Ordinance and may, by general or special order, provide for the distribution or allocation of work to be performed by them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Controller shall perform his functions and discharge his duties under the general supervision and control of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance and of such orders as may, from time to time, be made by the Government in this behalf, the Deputy Controllers and Assistant Controllers shall perform their functions and discharge their duties under the general supervision and control of the Controller.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Constitution of Advisory Committee</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Government may constitute an Advisory Committee to be called the Hotels and Restaurants Advisory Committee, consisting of as many members as the Government may determine, to aid and advise the Government in relation to such matters relating to the administration of this Ordinance as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The members of the Committee shall be appointed for such period and on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government shall appoint a Chairman of the Committee from among its members.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration of hotels and restaurants</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The owner of every hotel and restaurant shall, within a period of two months from the commencement of this Ordinance, or from the date of opening of the hotel or restaurant, whichever is later, apply to the Controller for registration of his hotel or restaurant and, in the case of a hotel, also for its classification, on payment of such fees as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) <strong>No hotel or restaurant shall be registered unless</strong>-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)it conforms to the prescribed standard of health, hygiene and comfort:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Controller may allow provisional registration subject to such conditions as he may deem fit and, for good and sufficient reasons, modify, alter or withdraw any such condition at any time;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)it furnishes at its expense certificates of medical fitness from a Civil Surgeon in respect of its staff in such form as may be prescribed;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)the building is structurally safe and adequately protected against fire or an accident arising out of electricity or gas and safety of the guests or customers is ensured.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Controller, or an officer authorised by him in this behalf, or a member of the Committee, may, at any time, inspect the premises of a hotel or restaurant, call for any information, plan or data in respect of any matter concerning such hotel or restaurant or, at the cost of the owner, carry out, or require the owner to carry out, test of any articles or appliances or foodstuff.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Classification of hotels</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. Subject to such general or particular direction as the Government may issue, the Controller shall, according to the prescribed minimum criteria, by notification in the official Gazette, classify hotels according to the star classification system, as-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) one star hotels, being hotels which conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of hotels of that class but do not conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of a higher star class hotel;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) two star hotels, being hotels which conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of hotels of that class, but do not conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of a higher star class hotel;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) three star hotels, being hotels which conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of hotels of that class, but do not conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of a higher star class hotel;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Four star hotels, being hotels which conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of hotels of that class but do not conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of a higher star class hotel; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) Five star hotels, being hotels which conform to the prescribed minimum criteria of hotels of that class.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Issue of Licence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7.
