The Board may, by general or special order in writing, direct that such of its powers shall in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercisable also by the Chairman, the Rector, a member or by such officer of the Center as may be so specified:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no power to make regulations under section 20 shall be delegated under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Funds of the Center</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The funds of the Center shall comprise-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        grants made by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        grants from the local authorities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        loans obtained from the Government and local authorities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        sale proceeds and royalties accruing from the property owned by the Center;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        receipts from any other source.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The funds of the Center shall be kept in a scheduled Bank approved by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Budget of the Center</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. The Center shall, by such date in each year as may be specified by the Government, submit to the Government for approval a budget for each financial year showing the estimated receipts and expenditure and the sums which are likely to be required from the Government during that financial year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Audit and accounts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) The Center shall maintain its accounts in such manner and form as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts of the Center shall be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of Bangladesh, hereinafter in this section referred to as the Auditor-General, in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of an audit under sub-section (2), the Auditor-General or any person authorised by him in this behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash, securities, stores and other property of the Center and may examine the Chairman or any member or any officer or employee of the Center.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Auditor General shall, as soon as possible after completion of the audit, send to the Board his audit report and the Board shall forward it, with its comments thereon, to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Center shall take steps forthwith to remedy any defect or irregularity pointed out in the audit report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Submission of annual report, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) The Center shall as soon as possible after the end of every financial year, submit to the Government an annual report on the conduct of its affairs for that year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may require the Center to furnish any report, return, statement, estimate, statistics or other information regarding any matter under the control of the Centre and the Center shall comply with every such requisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Certain training organisations to cease to exist, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any regulation, resolution, agreement, contract or other instrument, on the commencement of this Ordinance-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)  Bangladesh Administrative Staff College, National Institute of Public Administration, Civil Officer Training Academy, Staff Training Institute and Regional Staff Training Institutes, hereinafter referred to as the said training organisations, shall cease to exist;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)  all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all properties, movable or immovable, cash and bank balances, reserved funds, investments and all other rights and interest in, or arising out of, such properties and all books of accounts, registers, records and all other documents of whatever nature relating thereto, of the said training organisations shall stand transferred to, and vest in, the Center;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)    all debts, liabilities and obligations incurred, all contracts entered into and all matters and things engaged to be done by, with or for, the said training organisations before such commencement, shall be deemed to have been incurred, entered into or engaged to be done by, with or for, the Center;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)    all suits, prosecutions and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said training organisations shall be deemed to have been instituted by or against the Centre and may be continued or proceeded with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)     every person serving in connection with the affairs of the said training organisations shall stand transferred to the Center and shall serve the Center on such terms and conditions, not being disadvantageous to him, as the Government may determine, and the person so transferred shall, except in the matter of dismissal, removal or reduction in rank, be subject to the power and control of the Center in the same manner and to the same extent as, any officer or employee appointed by the Center.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, for the purposes of removing any difficulty in relation to the transfer and other matters specified in sub-section (1), make such orders as it may consider expedient and any such order shall be deemed to be, and given effect to as, part of the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall lie against the Board, the Chairman, the Rector or any member of the Board or any officer or employee of the Center for anything done or intended to be done in good faith under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) The Board may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Ordinance or rules made thereunder, to provide for all matters for which provision is necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All regulations made under this section shall be published in the official Gazette and shall come into force on such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 Clause (ff) was inserted by section 2 of the Bangladesh Public Administration Training Center (Amendment) Ordinance, 1986 (Ordinance No. XXXVII of 1986)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 Clause (g) was substituted by section 2 of the Bangladesh Public Administration Training Center (Amendment) Ordinance, 1986 (Ordinance No. XXXVII of 1986</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
624	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH RAILWAY BOARD (REPEAL) ORDINANCE 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH RAILWAY BOARD (REPEAL) ORDINANCE 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXIV OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[30th May, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal the Bangladesh Railway Board Ordinance 1976.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal the Bangladesh Railway Board Ordinance 1976 (XLI of 1976), and to provide for matters ancillary thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Railway Board (Repeal) Ordinance, 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal of Ord No XLI of 1976</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) The Bangladesh Railway Board Ordinance, 1976 (XLI of 1976), hereinafter referred to as the said Ordinance, is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the repeal of the said Ordinance,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Bangladesh Railway Board, hereinafter referred to as the said Board, constituted under the said Ordinance shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all property, movable and immovable, cash and bank balances, reserve funds, investments and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such property, and all books of accounts, registers, records and all other documents of the said Board shall stand transferred to, and vest in, the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all debts and liabilities incurred, all obligations undertaken, all contracts entered into and all agreements made by or with the said Board before such repeal shall be deemed to have been incurred, undertaken, entered into or made by or with the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said Board before such repeal shall be deemed to be suits and proceedings by or against the Government and shall be proceeded or otherwise dealt with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        all officers and other employees of the said Board shall stand transferred to and become officers and employees of the Government and shall hold office or service under the Government on the same terms and conditions as were applicable to them immediately before such repeal and shall continue to do so until their terms and conditions are duly altered by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         all Provident Funds established, maintained or managed by the said Board and existing immediately before such repeal shall continue to exist and the subscriptions and contributions thereto shall be credited to the Government and the Government shall be liable to make payment to the officers and employees concerned out of those Funds.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
625	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH RURAL DEVELOPMENT BOARD ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH RURAL DEVELOPMENT BOARD ORDINANCE, 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. LIII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[13th December, 19822]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the establishment of the Bangladesh Rural Development Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the establishment of a Board for rural development in Bangladesh to formulate policies, co-ordinate activities and supervise implementation of various projects and programmes relating to rural development and for development of rural economy of the country and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Rural Development Board Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Board” means the Bangladesh Rural Development Board established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “cooperative society” shall have the same meaning as assigned to it in the Cooperative Societies Act, 1940 (Ben. Act XXI of 1940);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “Director-General” means the Director-General of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “member” means a member of the Board and includes the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “prescribe” means prescribed by rules; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “TCCA” means the Thana Central Cooperative Association registered under the Cooperative Societies Act, 1940 (Ben. Act XXI of 1940).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Establishment of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, establish a Board to be called the Bangladesh Rural Development Board for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall be a body corporate having perpetual succession and a common seal, with power, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder, to acquire, hold and dispose of property both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Head Office, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Head Office of the Board shall be at Dhaka.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board may establish offices at such other places as it deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Constitution and composition of the Board, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The Board shall consist of the following members, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        The Minister-in-charge of the Ministry of Local Government, who shall also be the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        The Secretary of the Rural Development and Cooperative Division or Additional Secretary or Joint Secretary-in-charge of that Division, ex-officio, who shall also be the Vice-Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        An officer not below the rank of a Joint Secretary from each of the Divisions of Agriculture and Forests, Fisheries and Livestock, Finance, Energy, Irrigation, Water Development and Flood Control and Local Government, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        Member, Planning Commission, in-charge of rural development, or an officer not below the rank of a Section Chief, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        The Chairman of the Bangladesh Agriculture Development Corporation, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         The Directors of the Bangladesh Rural Development Academies, Comilla and Bogra, alternatively for one year by rotation, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        The Registrar of Cooperative Societies, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        The Chairman, Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries Corporation, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         Five members to be elected by the National Federation of the TCCAs;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         One member to be nominated by the Government from such major financial institutions as may be determined by the Government financing the TCCAs;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        One member to be nominated by the Bangladesh Jatiya Samabaya Union;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         The Director-General of the Board, ex-officio, who shall also be the Member-Secretary of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The elected and nominated members shall hold office for a period of one year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) No act done by the Board shall be invalid on the ground merely of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution or composition of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Meetings of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (a) The meetings of the Board shall be held at least six times in each calendar year, and at least once in every two months.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        A notice in writing shall be given by the Member-Secretary for each meeting of the Board and such written notice shall include agenda of the meeting.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        Except with the consent of the Chairman and a majority of the members present, no business other than that for which the meeting was convened shall be discussed at a meeting of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        All questions at a meeting of the Board shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting, and in the case of equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a second and casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        To constitute a quorum of a meeting of the Board not less than five members shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Functions of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The functions of the Board shall be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to promote village-based primary co-operative societies and TCCAs with a view to enabling them to be autonomous, self-managed and financially viable vehicles for increasing production, employment generation and rural development;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to encourage functional cooperatives for generating income and employment for the rural poor;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        to promote intensive irrigated agriculture as a means to cooperative development and also for efficient utilisation, through the cooperatives, of irrigation facilities based on ground and surface water;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        to channel and ensure productive utilisation of institutional credit through the village cooperatives and the TCCAs and simultaneously promote members accumulation of shares and savings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        to encourage financially viable TCCAs to diversify activities specially in the marketing of agricultural inputs and produce as a service to their members;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         to arrange for effective training of members of the managing committee of village based primary cooperative societies and TCCAs and model farmers in the agricultural and rural Development Activities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        to liaise with concerned Ministries, Departments and Agencies for mobilizing supplies, services and supports for the TCCAs and village cooperative system;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        to promote the District and National Federations of TCCAs with a view to progressively handing over the then promotional, motivational and educational functions in relation to rural development;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         to delegate to the Director General, Director and any other officer of the Board appropriate authorities and responsibilities for the achievements of the objectives of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         to delegate to the district and thana level officers of the Board, maximum possible financial and administrative authority to achieve the objectives of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        to submit to Government project and programmes consistent with its objectives and to implement them with Government approval;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         to approve the annual development programmes and the annual budget of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       to engage competent evaluation teams and research institutions to study and evaluate the progress made and problems faced in the implementation of, and in achieving the objectives of, the projects and programmes undertaken by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        to take such measures and exercise such other powers as it considers necessary for carrying out its functions under the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions of sub section (1), the Board may for the performance of its functions:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) undertake any work, incur any expenditure within the approved budget or any special allocation of funds, procure machinery, materials and services required for its use and enter into any agreement or contract as it may consider necessary or expedient;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        seek or obtain advice and assistance in the preparation or creation of a scheme from the Government, any agency of the Government, local body or any other agency or, with the permission of the Government, from any foreign Government or agency.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Director General, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) There shall be appointed by the Government a Director General who shall be the chief executive officer of the Board with responsibilities for carrying out the decisions and performing the executive functions of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) There shall be appointed by the Government such number of Directors of the Board as it may fix from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Director-General and the Directors shall hold office for such period and on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) If the Director-General is, for illness, or for any other reason, incapable of performing his duties under this Ordinance, the Government may authorise any Director to perform the duties of the Director-General during the period for which he is so incapable.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Funds</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) There shall be three Funds of the Board, namely, the Rural Development Fund, the Special Projects Fund and the Board Operating Fund.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Rural Development Fund shall be utilised for channelling to the village based primary cooperative societies and TCCAs for their promotional, motivational and developmental activities.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Special Projects Fund shall be utilised for undertaking specific and well defined tasks assigned to the Board by the Government or for execution of special projects for which special agreement have been signed between the Government and the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Board Operating Fund shall be utilised for the pay and allowances of the Director-General, Directors, officers and staff and for all other operational and incidental expenses of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Grants, etc, to the Funds</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) To the credit of the Rural Development Fund shall be placed-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) grants made by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        loans obtained by the Board from the Government or any other source with the approval of Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        grants made to the Board by local authorities or cooperative bodies;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        all other sums received by the Board from any other source; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        interest or other income on the above amounts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To the credit of the Special Projects Fund shall be placed-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        grants received from the Government or agencies approved by the Government; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        loans received from the Government or agencies approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) To the credit of the Board Operating Fund shall be placed-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        grants obtained by the Board from the Government or agencies approved by the Government; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        loans obtained by the Board from the Government or agencies approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Borrowing power</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. The Board may, with the prior approval of the Government, borrow money from any source in Bangladesh for carrying out the purposes of the Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Budget</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Board shall, by such date before the commencement of each financial year as the Government may direct, submit to the Government for approval a budget, in the prescribed form, for each financial year showing the estimated expenditures and receipts, if any, and the sums likely to be required from the Government during the financial year for each of the Funds specified in section 9.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Audit and Accounts</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Board shall maintain its accounts in such manner and form as the Government may prescribe.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts of the Board shall be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor General of Bangladesh, hereinafter in this section referred to as the Auditor General, in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of an audit under sub section (2) the Auditor General or any person authorised by him in this behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash securities, stores and other property of the Board and may examine the Director General or any Director or any officer or employee of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Auditor General shall, as soon as possible after completion of the audit, send to the Board his audit report and the Board shall forward it with its comments thereon to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Board shall take steps forthwith to remedy the defects or irregularities pointed out in the audit report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Three level functionaries</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Board's functions shall be at three levels, namely, the National level, the district level and the thana level.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The strength of the officers and members of the staff and their functions at each level shall be determined by the Board with the prior approval of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appointment of officers, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. The Board may, subject to the overall sanctioned strength and budgetary provisions and also subject to regulations as may be made under the Ordinance in this behalf, create such posts of officers, consultants, advisers, auditors and other employees as it considers necessary for the efficient discharge of its functions under this Ordinance and appoint them on such terms and conditions as the Board may determine</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Submission of reports, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) The Board shall submit to the Government, as soon as possible after the end of every financial year, a detailed report on the conduct of its affairs for that year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall submit to the Government at such time and at such interval as the Government may specify-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) such returns, accounts, statements, estimates and statistics as may be required by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        information and comments asked for by the Government on any specific subject;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        copies of documents required by the Government for examination or any other purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Delegation of powers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. The Board may, by general or special order, direct that such of its powers shall, in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercisable by the Director-General, a Director or an officer of the Board as may be specified therein.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Public Servant, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. A member shall, while acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any provision of this Ordinance or rules and regulations made thereunder, be deemed to be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code (Act XLV of 1860).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Indemnity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Chairman, any member, adviser, consultant, officer or other employee of the Board for anything done or intended to be done in good faith under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to issue directions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. The Government may, from time to time, issue directions to the Board to take such measures as it considers necessary for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance; and the Board shall comply with all such directions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Removal of difficulties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Government may make such order, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, as may appear to it to be necessary for the purpose of removing the difficulty.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make rules</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make regulations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. (1) The Board may, with the prior approval of the Government, make regulations, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder, to provide for all matters for which provision is necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All regulations made under this section shall be published in the official Gazette and shall come into force on such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Winding up</p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. No provision of law relating to the winding up of bodies corporate shall apply to the Board, and the Board shall not be wound up except by order of the Government, and in such manner as the Government may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Dissolution of Integrated Rural Development Programme</p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any rule, regulation or bye-law, or in any contract or agreement, upon the establishment of the Board-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Integrated Rural Development Programme, hereinafter referred to as the IRDP, shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        all properties, movable and immovable, all rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government relating to the IRDP shall stand transferred to and vest in the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        every person in the service of the Republic serving in or in connection with the affairs of the IRDP shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or agreement or in the terms and conditions of service, serve, if so required by the Government, under the Board; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        anything done, action taken, order passed, appointment made, notification issued, or purported to have been done, taken, passed, made or issued, by the Government in respect of the IRDP after the 16th day of December, 1971, and before the commencement of this Ordinance, shall be deemed to have been validly done, taken, passed, made or issued and shall have and shall be deemed always to have had effect accordingly, and shall not be called in question in any Court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
626	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH STANDARDS AND TESTING INSTITUTION ORDINANCE 1985</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH STANDARDS AND TESTING INSTITUTION ORDINANCE 1985</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO XXXVII OF 1985).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[25th July, 1985]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the establishment of an Institution for standardisation, testing, metro logy, quality control, grading and marking of goods. WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the establishment of an Institution for standardisation, testing, metro logy, quality control, grading and marking of goods and for matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Ordinance 1985.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2.  (1) In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “article” means any substance, artificial or natural, or partly artificial or partly natural, whether raw or partly or wholly processed or manufactured;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Bangladesh Standard” means the national standard of Bangladesh established and published by the Institution, in relation to any article or process, indicative of the quality and specification of such article or process, and includes-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) any provisional standard, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) any  international standard adopted by the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “calibration” means quantitative determination of the errors of a measuring device and, where necessary, adjusting of these errors to a minimum;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “Council” means the Council of the Institution constituted under section 7;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) “covering” includes any stopper, cask bottle, vessel, box, crate, cover, capsule, case, frame, wrapper or other container;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) “Director General” means Director General of the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) “Inspector” means an Inspector appointed under Section 25 and includes any officer of the Institute authorised by the Director General to act as Inspector;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) “grading” means classification of a material in conformity with a set standard;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) “Institution” means the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ (jj) “label” means the display of written, printed or graphic matter on any product, its container, tag or literature of the product or other suitable material affixed thereto for the purpose of giving information as to the identity, components, ingredients, attributes, direction for use, specifications (including weights or quantity), date of manufacturing or expiry;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) “licence” means a licence granted under section 20 to use the Standard Mark in relation to any article or process which conforms to the Bangladesh Standard;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) “mark” includes a device, brand, heading, label, ticket, pictorial representation, name, signature, word, letter or numeral or any combination thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       “prescribed” means prescribed by regulations made under section 37;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        “process” includes any practice, treatment and mode of manufacture of any article;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o)        “registering authority” means any authority competent under any law for the time being in force to register any company, firm, or other body of persons, or any trade mark or design, or to grant a patent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p)        “simplification” means reduction of unnecessary sizes and varieties of a material;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q)       “specification” means a description of an article or process as far as practicable by reference to its nature, quality, strength, purity, composition, quantity, dimensions, weight, grade, durability, origin, age, material, mode of manufacture or other characteristics to distinguish it from any other article or process;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(r)     “Standard Mark” means the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Certification Mark specified by the Institution to represent a particular Bangladesh Standard;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(s) “Standardisation” means setting up of standards;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(t) “test report” means certificate of test in respect of quality or grade of a material;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(u) “trade mark” means a mark used, or proposed to be used, in relation to goods for the purpose of indicating, or so as to indicate, a connection in the course of trade between the goods and some persons having the right, either as proprietor or as registered user, to use the mark whether with or without any indication of the identity of that person.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)    An article is said to be marked with a Standard Mark if the article itself is marked with Standard Mark, or any covering containing, or label attached to, such article is so marked.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Establishment and incorporation of the Institution</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.   (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, establish an Institution to be called the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)   The Institution shall be a body corporate having perpetual succession and a common seal with power, among others, to acquire, hold, manage and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Head Office, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Head Office of the Institution shall be at Dhaka.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Institution may establish offices and branches at such other places as it may think fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The functions of the Institution</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5.         The functions of the Institution shall be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to set up Bangladesh Standards of quality and dimensions and prepare and promote the general adoption of standards on national and international basis relating to materials, commodities, structures, practices and operations and, from time to time, withdraw, revise, alter and amend the same;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to consider and recommend to the Government Bangladesh Standards for the measurement of length, weight, mass, volume and energy;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)  to promote standardisation, quality control, metro logy and simplification in industry and commerce;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)  to secure compliance with the Bangladesh Standards adopted by the Institution by the producers and users;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)  to implement Bangladesh Standards through the administration of a national certification mark scheme or inspection of goods or both;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)    to provide or arrange facilities for examination, testing and inspection of commodities, processes and practices for any investigation, research, or promotion of export that may be necessary and to issue test reports;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)   to certify the quality of commodities, materials, produces, products and other things including food materials, whether for local consumption, export or import;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)    to co-ordinate the efforts of producers and users for the improvement of materials, products, code of practice, appliances, processes and methods, so as to eliminate the national waste of material and time involved in the production of an unnecessary variety of patterns and sizes of articles for one and the same purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) to establish and publish, in such manner as may be prescribed, the Bangladesh Standard Specifications in relation to any article or process or code of practice;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)  to recognise, adopt or endorse as a Bangladesh Standard, in such manner as may be prescribed, any standard established by any other Institution in Bangladesh or in any foreign country, or by international organisations in relation to any article or process;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) to specify a Standard Mark to be called the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Certification Mark which shall be of such design and contain such particulars as may be prescribed to represent a particular Bangladesh Standard;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)   to grant, renew, reject, suspend or cancel, in such manner as may be prescribed, a licence for the use of Standard Mark;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m) to make such inspection and take such samples of any material or substance as may be necessary to see whether any article or process in relation to which the Standard Mark has been used or proposed to be used conforms to the Bangladesh Standard or whether the Standard Mark has been improperly used in relation to any article or process with or without licence;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)  to utilise, with the permission of the owners, the services of laboratories other than those maintained by the Institution and approve such laboratories for the purpose of the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o)   to make arrangements, or provide for the facilities, for the testing and calibration of precision instruments, gauges, and scientific apparatus and for the issue of certificates in regard thereto so as to make them comply with the required standards;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p)    to undertake execution of any trust or any agency business which it may consider conducive to the attainment of its objectives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q)  to co-operate with any person, association or organisation outside Bangladesh having objectives similar to those for which the Institution is established;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(qq) to grade and mark agricultural produce in a manner provided in the Agricultural Produce Grading and Marking Act, 1937 (Act No. I of 1937) and the rules framed thereunder for the purposes of export; and]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(r)  to do all such acts and things ancillary or incidental to any of the aforesaid functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">General direction of the affairs and functions of the Institution</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6.   (1) The general direction and administration of the affairs and functions of the Institution shall vest in a Council which may exercise all powers and perform all functions which may be exercised or performed by the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Council shall, in discharging its duties, be guided by such instructions as may be given to it by the Government from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Composition of the Council</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. 5[ (1) The council shall consist of the following members, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Minister-in-charge of Ministry of Industries, ex-officio, who shall also be the Chairman of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the State Minister, Ministry of Industries, ex-officio, who shall also be the Vice-Chairman of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the Secretary, Ministry of Industries, ex-officio, who shall also be the Vice-Chairman of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the Inspector General of Police, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        Principal Information Officer, Department of Press Information, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         the Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        the Director General, Bangladesh Television, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        the Director General, Bangladesh Betar, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         one member, not below the rank of Joint Secretary, each to represent the Ministries and Divisions specified in Part-I of the Schedule to the nominated by the respective Ministries and Divisions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         the President or the Chairman of the organisations specified in Part-II of the Schedule;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        the chief executive of the bodies specified in Part-III of the Schedule;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         the Director General, ex-officio, who shall also act as the Secretary of the Council.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        A member other than an ex-officio member shall hold office for a term of three years from the date of his nomination:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where a person is nominated to be a member by reason of his holding an office or appointment he shall cease to be such member when he ceases to hold that office or appointment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        A person nominated to be a member may, at any time, resign his office by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no resignation shall take effect until it has been accepted by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) No act or proceedings of the Council shall be invalid merely on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Meetings of the Council</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8.  (1) The meetings of the Council shall be held at such times and places as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that until so prescribed such meetings shall be held at such times and places as may be determined by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To constitute a quorum at a meeting of the Council, not less than eight members shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All questions at a meeting of the Council shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting, and, in case of equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a second or casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"> (4) All meetings of the Council shall be presided over by the Chairman or, in his absence, by the first Vice-Chairman or, in the absence of Chairman and first Vice-Chairman, the second Vice-Chairman or, in the absence of all, by a member elected for that purposed by the members present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of Committees</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) The Council may appoint such Committee or Committees as it thinks fit to assist it in the discharge of its functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Each Committee shall be headed by a Chairman and shall consist of such members as may be determined by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Chairman and members of a Committee shall hold office for such period as may be determined by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Association with the Council, etc of persons not being members</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The Council or any Committee appointed under section 9 may associate with itself any person whose assistance or advice it may desire for carrying out any of its functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any person associated with the Council or any Committee appointed under section 9 shall have a right to take part in the discussion at a meeting of the Council or of the Committee, as the case may be, but shall not have a right to vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) There shall be a Director General of the Institution who shall be appointed by the Government on such terms and conditions as it may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Director General shall be the principal executive officer of the Institution and shall be responsible for the proper administration of the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Director General</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) There shall be a Director General of the Institution who shall be appointed by the Government on such terms and conditions as it may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Director General shall be the principal executive officer of the Institution and shall be responsible for the proper administration of the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of Officers, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Institution may appoint such officers and other employees as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as may be determined by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Funds of the Institution</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) There shall be a fund of the Institution to which shall be credited-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        grants and loans from the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        income from investment, royalties and properties; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all other receipts of the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The fund of the Institution shall be utilised by it to meet charges in connection with its functions under this Ordinance and all payments of the Institution shall be made out of the fund.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All moneys of the Institution shall be kept in such bank or banks specified in the Schedule to the Bangladesh Banks (Nationalisation) Order, 1972 (P.O. No. 26 of 1972), as may be decided by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Accounts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. The Institution shall keep its accounts in such manner as the Government may determine in consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor General of Bangladesh, hereinafter referred to as the Auditor General.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Budget</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. The Institution shall, by such date in each year as may be fixed by the Government, submit to the Government for approval a budget in such form as the Government may specify for each financial year showing the estimated receipts and expenditure during that financial year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Audit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) The accounts of the Institution shall be audited by the Auditor General in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) For the purpose of an audit under sub-section (1), the Auditor General or any person authorised by him in this behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash, securities, stores and other property of the Institution and may examine any member, the Director General or any other officer or employee of the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)  The Auditor General shall submit his audit report to the Government and shall forward a copy thereof to the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Reports, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Institution shall furnish to the Government such reports and statements as the Government may, from time to time, require.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)The Institution shall, as soon as possible after the end of every financial year, furnish to the Government a statement of audited accounts together with an annual report on the condition of its affairs of that year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Authentication of orders and other instruments of the Institution</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. All orders and decisions of, and all other instruments issued by, the Institution shall be authenticated by the signature of such officer or officers as may be authorised by the Council in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition of improper use of Standard Mark</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) Except under a licence granted under section 20, no person shall use in relation to any article or process or in the title of any patent, or in any trade mark or design, the Standard Mark or any colourable imitation thereof.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding that a licence has been granted under section 20, no person shall use, in relation to any article or process, the Standard Mark or any colourable imitation thereof unless such article or process conforms to the Bangladesh Standard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Grant of licence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) Any person who intends to use, in relation to any article or process or in the title of any patent, or in any trade mark or design, the Standard Mark shall apply to the Institution, in such form as may be prescribed, for grant of a licence for such use.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Institution may grant a licence if, after such enquiry as it deems necessary, it is satisfied that-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)   the article or process in respect of which the Standard Mark is to be used conforms to the related Bangladesh Standard; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        there is arrangement for routine inspection and testing to ensure that the article or process concerned conforms to the related Bangladesh Standard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A licence shall be granted in such form and on payment of such fee as may be prescribed, and may be subject to such conditions as may be specified therein by the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A licence granted under this section shall remain valid for a period of three years:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Institution may revoke the licence at any time, if it is satisfied that the licensee has violated any condition specified in the licence:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further that no licence shall be revoked unless the licensee is given a reasonable opportunity of being heard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition of use of certain names, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. Except in such cases and under such conditions as may be prescribed, no person shall, without the previous permission of the Institution, use-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any name which so nearly resembles the name of the Institution as to deceive or likely to deceive the public or which contains expressions “Bangladesh Standard” or “Bangladesh Standard Specification” or any abbreviation of such expressions; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any mark or trade mark in relation to any article or process containing the expressions “Bangladesh Standard” or “Bangladesh Standard Specification” or any abbreviation of such expressions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition of registration in certain cases</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force, no registering authority shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        register any company, firm or other body of persons which bears any name, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        register a trade mark or design which bears any name or mark, if the use of such name or mark is in contravention of section 19 or section 21.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any question arises before a registering authority whether the use of any name or mark is in contravention of section 19 or section 21, the registering authority may refer the question to the Government whose decision thereon shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to prohibit or restrict export of certain articles</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. (1) The Government may, in consultation with the Institution, by notification in the official Gazette and subject to such conditions and exceptions as may be made by or under the notification, prohibit, restrict or otherwise control the taking out of Bangladesh of articles of any specified description which do not bear the Standard Mark or regulate generally all practices (including trade practices) and procedures connected with the export of such articles.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No articles of the specified description shall be taken out of Bangladesh except in accordance with the conditions of a licence to be issued by an officer authorised in this behalf by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All articles to which any notification under sub-section (1) applies shall be deemed to be goods the taking of which out of Bangladesh has been prohibited or restricted under section 16 of the Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969) and all provisions of the said Act shall have effect accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to prohibit the sale 7[ ] of certain articles</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. (1) The Government may, in consultation with the Institution, by notification in the official Gazette, prohibit with effect from such date as may be specified in the notification, the sale 8[ , distribution and commercial advertisement] of any article specified therein which does not conform to the Bangladesh Standard established by the Institution in relation to that article:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the date specified in the notification shall be a date not earlier than two months from the date of publication of the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, require any article which conforms to a particular Bangladesh Standard to be marked with the Standard Mark.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Inspectors</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. (1) The Institution may appoint as many Inspectors as may be necessary for the purpose of inspecting whether any article or process in relation to which the Standard Mark has been used conforms to the Bangladesh Standard or whether the Standard Mark has been improperly used in relation to any article or process, with or without licence and for the purpose of discharging such other duties as may be assigned to them.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Subject to any regulations made under this Ordinance, an Inspector shall have power-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to inspect any operation carried on in connection with any article or process in relation to which the Standard Mark has been used;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to take samples of any article, or of any material or substance used in any article or process, in relation to which the Standard Mark has been used; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9[ (bb) to search, size and investigate in respect of an offence under this Ordinance as a Police officer of the rank or Sub-Inspector.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        to exercise such other powers as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Every Inspector shall be furnished by the Institution with a certificate of appointment as an Inspector, and the certificate shall, on demand, be produced by the Inspector.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to obtain information, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. Every licensee shall supply the Institution with such information, and with such samples of any material or substance used in relation to any article or process, as the Institution may require.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Delegation of powers</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. The Institution may, by general or special order in writing, direct that such of its powers shall, in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercisable also by the Chairman or by the Director-General or by any member of the Council or by any officer of the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appeals</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. (1) Any person aggrieved by an order passed under clause (1) of section 5 may prefer an appeal to the Government within three months from the date of receipt of the decision or within such further time as may be allowed by the Government on payment of such fee as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may call for relevant papers from the Institution and may, after such inquiry in the matter as it considers necessary, pass such order as it thinks fit and any such order passed by the Government shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Certain matters to be kept confidential</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. Any information obtained by an Inspector or by a member of the Council or any officer or other employee of the Institution from any statement made or information supplied or in any evidence given or from inspection made under the provisions of this Ordinance shall be treated as confidential:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to the disclosure of any information for the purpose of prosecution under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for improper use of Standard Mark, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. (1) Any person who contravenes the provisions of section 19 or section 21 or section 22 shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 10[ two years, or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand Taka but shall not be less than seven thousand Taka], or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A Court convicting a person under sub-section (1) may direct that any property in respect of which the contravention has taken place shall be forfeited to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for contravention of section 23</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. If any person contravenes the provisions of any notification under section 23 or of any licence issued thereunder, he shall, without prejudice to any confiscation or penalty to which he may be liable under the provisions of the Customs Act, 1969 (IV of 1969), as applied by section 23(3), be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to 11[ four years, or with fine which may extend to one lakh taka but shall not be less than seven thousand taka], or with both</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for contravention of section 24</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12[ 31A. Any person who contravenes the provisions of any notification under section 24 shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to four years, or with fine which may extend to one lakh taka but shall not be less than seven thousand taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for obstructing Inspector in discharge of his functions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">31B. Any person who voluntarily obstructs, or gives false information to, any Inspector in the discharge of his public functions shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand taka but shall not be less than seven thousand taka, or with both.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for other offences</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. Whoever contravenes any of the provisions of this Ordinance or of any regulation made or notification issued thereunder shall, if no other penalty is elsewhere provided by or under this Ordinance for such contravention, be punishable with fine 13[ which may extend to fifty thousand taka but shall not be less than seven thousand taka].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cognizance of offences</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14[ 33. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898)-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) no Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under this Ordinance except upon a complaint in writing, made by an Inspector authorised by the Government or the institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) no Court inferior to that of a Metropolitan Magistrate or a Magistrate of the first class shall try any offence under this Ordinance.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Place and Procedure of trial</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15[ 33A. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898)-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) an offence punishable under this Ordinance may be tried at any place within the local jurisdiction of the Metropolitan Magistrate or of the Magistrate of the first class;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) an offence punishable under this Ordinance may be tried summarily in accordance with, as far as possible, the provisions laid down in Chapter XXII of the said Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Articles liable to confiscation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33B. (1) Whenever any offence under this Ordinance has been committed, the articles or any other thing is respect of which or by which such offence has been committed, shall be liable to confiscation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any article liable to confiscation under this Ordinance shall, as soon as the order for confiscation has been made, be delivered to the Director General who shall arrange its disposal through destruction or any other method as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to close any factory, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33C. (1) If, after examination, it is found that any article which does not conform to the Bangladesh Standard established by the Institution in relation to that article, the Director General may, by an order in writing, close, in such manner as may be prescribed, the factory producing such article or the premises where such article are stored, kept or traded.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Any person against whom an order of closure has been made under sub-section (1) may appeal to the Government within thirty days from the date of such order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>:- For the purposes of this section “premises” includes-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a place where any business, industry, production or trade is carried on by a person, whether by himself or through an agent, by whatever name called;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b         a warehouse, godown or other place where any article or articles are stored, exhibited or traded;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        a dwelling house, if any part thereof is used for the purpose of carrying on any business, industry, production or trade; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        a vehicle or vessel or any other mobile device, help of which any trade or business is carried on.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Special Provision regarding fines</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33D. Notwithstanding anything contained in section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898), it shall be lawful for any Metropolitan Magistrate or Magistrate of the first class to pass a sentence of fine under this Ordinance exceeding ten thousand taka.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">34. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Government or the Institution or any person acting under the authority of the Government or the Institution for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done in pursuance of this Ordinance or any regulation made thereunder</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Ordinance not to affect the operation of certain Acts</p><p style="text-align: justify;">35. Nothing in this Ordinance shall affect the operation of 16[ * * *] the Drugs Act, 1940 (XXIII of 1940).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Abolition of Central Testing Laboratories</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17[ 36. (1) Upon the establishment of the Institution,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the laboratories known as the Central Testing Laboratories belonging to the Government, hereinafter referred to as the said Laboratories, shall stand abolished;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all assets and properties and all rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government in relation to the said Laboratories shall, unless the Government otherwise directs, be transferred to, and vest in, the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        all officers and other employees of the said Laboratories shall stand transferred to the Institution, but shall continue to be Government servants and hold their office or service in the Institution on deputation and be governed in respect of all matters relating to the terms and conditions of their service by the laws, rules and regulations applicable to Government servants:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that any such officer or employee may, within such period as may be specified by the Government by order, exercise his option not to continue as Government servants, where upon such officer or employee shall cease to be Government servant and shall become officer or employee of the Institution and shall serve the Institution on the same terms and conditions as were applicable to them immediately before their transfer to the Institution unless such terms and conditions are altered, not being to their disadvantage, by the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All officers and other employees holding their office or service in the Institution under clause(c) of sub-section (1) shall be eligible for promotion to any post of the Institution and for that purpose a common seniority list of all officers and other employees of the Institution shall be prepared by the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Institution shall bear all expenses required for, and in connection with, the pay, provident fund, gratuity, pension and other financial benefits of the officers and other employees holding their office or service in the Institution under clause (c) of sub-section (1).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Abolition of Department of Agricultural Marketing and Grading</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18[ 36A. (1) The Department of Agriculture Marketing and Grading of the Government, hereinafter referred to as the said Department, shall be deemed to have stood abolished with effect from the date of 11th December, 1995.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All assets and properties and all rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government in relation to the said Department shall be deemed to have been transferred to, and vested in, the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All officers and other employees of the said Department shall be deemed to have stood transferred to the Institution, but shall continue to be Government servants and hold their office or service in the Institution on deputation and be governed in respect of all matters relating to the terms and conditions of their service by the laws, rules and regulations applicable to Government servants.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) All officers and other employees holding their office or service in the Institution under sub-section (3) shall be eligible for promotion to any post of the Institution and for that purpose a common seniority list of all officers and other employees of the Institution shall be prepared by the Institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Institution shall bear all expenses required for, and in connection with, the pay, provident fund, gratuity, pension and other financial benefits of the officers and other employees holding their office or service in the Institution under sub-section (3).]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">37. (1) The Institution may, with the previous approval of the Government, make regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, to provide for all matters for which provisions are necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All regulations made under sub-section (1) shall be published in the official Gazette and shall come into force on such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">38. (1) Upon the establishment of the Institution, the Bangladesh Standards Institution Ordinance, 1977 (XXXIX of 1977), hereinafter referred to as the said Ordinance, shall stand repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon such repeal,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the Bangladesh Standards Institution established under the said Ordinance, hereinafter referred to as the dissolved Institutions shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all property, movable and immovable, cash and bank balances, reserve funds, investments and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such property, and all books of accounts, registers, records and all other documents of the dissolved Institution shall stand transferred to, and vest in, the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all debts and liabilities incurred, all obligations undertaken, all contracts entered into and all agreements made by or with the dissolved Institution before such repeal shall be deemed to have been incurred, undertaken, entered into or made by or with the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the dissolved Institution before such repeal shall be deemed to be suits and proceedings by or against the Institution and shall be proceeded or otherwise dealt with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) all officers and other employees of the dissolved Institution shall stand transferred to and become officers and employees of the Institution and shall hold office or service under the Institution on the same terms and conditions as were applicable to them immediately before such repeal and shall continue to do so until their terms and conditions are duly altered by the Institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">f) all Provident Funds established, maintained or managed by the dissolved Institution and existing immediately before such repeal shall continue to exist and the subscriptions and contributions thereto shall be credited to the Institution and the Institution shall be liable to make payment to the officers and employees concerned out of these Funds.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word “international” was substituted for the word “foreign” by section 2 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 The words and figure “Section 25 and includes any officer of the Institute authorised by the Director General to act as Inspector” were substituted for the word and figure “Section 25” by section 2 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Clause (jj) was inserted by section 2 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The word “and” was omitted and thereafter the clause (qq) was inserted by section 3 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 Sub-section (1) was substituted by section 4 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 Sub-section (4) was substituted by section 5 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The word “international” was substituted for the word “foreign” by section 2 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The comma and words “, distribution and commercial advertisement” were substituted for the words “and distribution” by section 6 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 Clause (bb) was inserted by section 7 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 The words and comma “two years, or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand Taka but shall not be less than seven thousand Taka” were substituted for the words and comma “six months, or with fine which may extend to fifteen thousand taka” by section 8 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The words and comma “four years, or with fine which may extend to one lakh taka but shall not be less
