than seven thousand taka” were substituted for the words and comma “one year, or with fine” by section 9 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 Sections 31A and 31B were inserted by section 10 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13 The words “which may extend to fifty thousand taka but shall not be less than seven thousand taka” were substituted for the words “which may extend to five thousand taka” by section 11 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14 Section 33 was substituted by section 12 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15 Sections 33A, 33B, 33C and 33D were inserted by section 13 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16 The words, figures, brackets and commas “the Agricultural Produce (Grading and Marketing) Act, 1937 (I of 1937), or” were omitted by section 14 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17 Section 36 was substituted by section 2 of the Bangladesh Standard and Testing Institution (Amendment) Act, 1988 (Act No. XIX of 1988).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18 Section 36A was inserted by section 15 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institutes (Amendment) Act, 2003 (Act No. XXVII of 2003).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
627	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH UNANI AND AYURVEDIC PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH UNANI AND AYURVEDIC PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXII OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[17th July, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the regulation of the qualifications and registration of practitioners of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the regulation of the qualifications and registration of practitioners of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Unani and Ayurvedic Practitioners Ordinance, 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Board” means the Bangladesh Board of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Board;         (c) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules or regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “recognised” means recognised by the Government for the purposes of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “register” means a register of practitioners of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine maintained under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) “registered practitioner” means a practitioner whose name is for the time being entered in a register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) “Registrar” means the Registrar of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) “regulations” means regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) “rules” means rules made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) “Tabib” or “Hakim” means a practitioner of Unani system of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        “Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine” means the Unani Tib and Ayurvedic (including the Siddha) systems of medicine whether supplemented or not by such modern advances as the Board may, from time to time, determine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         “Vaid” or “Kabiraj” means a practitioner of Ayurvedic system of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Establishment and incorporation of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, establish a Board to be called the Bangladesh Board of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall be a body corporate, having perpetual succession and a common seal with power, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER II</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CONSTITUTION AND FUNCTIONS OF THE BOARD</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Composition of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Board shall consist of the following members, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        a Chairman to be appointed by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) two members to be nominated by the Government, of whom one each shall be from amongst the practising Hakims and Vaids;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        one member from each administrative division to be elected by the registered practitioners of Unani system of medicine from amongst themselves;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        one member from each administrative division to be elected by the registered practitioners of the Ayurvedic system of medicine from amongst themselves;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        two members to be nominated by the Government from amongst the teachers of recognised teaching institutions of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub section (1), for the purpose of constitution the Board for the first time, the members required to be elected under clauses (c) and (d) of that sub section, shall be nominated by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Elections</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Elections under this Ordinance shall be held at such time and place and in such manner as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Publication of names, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Government shall publish in the official Gazette, the names of the Chairman and other members of the Board together with the dates on which such members are nominated or elected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Term of office of members</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The members of the Board shall be nominated or elected, as the case may be, in such manner and for such term as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every member of the Board shall, subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance and the rules to be made thereunder, hold office until the election or nomination, as the case may be, of his successor at the end of the prescribed term.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Members shall be eligible for re nomination or re election to the Board on the expiry of the prescribed term.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) If a vacancy in the office of a member occurs during the prescribed term, through death, resignation, disability, or otherwise, the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with the provision of this Chapter and the member nominated or elected to fill the vacancy shall hold office until his successor is nominated or elected at the end of the prescribed term.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Vacancies not to invalidate proceedings of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid merely on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the composition of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Resignation from membership</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The Chairman may resign his office by letter addressed to the Government and any member may, at any time, resign his office by letter addressed to the Chairman and such resignation shall take effect from the date it is accepted by the Government or the Chairman, as the case may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Declaration of vacancies</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. If any member-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) absents himself, without such reason as may in the opinion of the Board be sufficient, from three consecutive ordinary meetings of the Board; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in section 11;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">the Board shall declare his office vacant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Disqualification of members</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. No person shall be a member of the Board if-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) he is an undischarged insolvent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) he has been adjudicated by a competent Court to be of unsound¬ mind;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) he has at any time been convicted of an offence, which in the opinion of the Government, involves moral turpitude.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Control over the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. If, in the opinion of the Government, anything done or intended to be done by or on behalf of the Board is not in conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance, or is in any way against the public interest, the Government may, by order,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        quash the proceedings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        suspend the execution of any resolution passed or order made by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        prohibit the doing of anything proposed to be done; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        require the Board to take such action as may be specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Functions of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. The following shall be the functions of the Board, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to consider applications for recognition under this Ordinance made by institutions imparting or desiring to impart instruction in the Unani or Ayurvedic systems of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to secure the maintenance of an adequate standard of efficiency in recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to make arrangement for the registrations of duly qualified persons in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to appoint committees and sub committees for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to hold examinations and confer certificates, diplomas or degrees in Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to provide for research in the Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine and to establish research centre or academy for this purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) to make arrangements for standardisation of the Unani and Ayurvedic medicines;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) to prepare and publish text books to meet the needs of teachers of Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) to publish journals, periodicals and bulletins on Unani and Ayurvedic systems of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j) to prepare and publish Unani and Ayurvedic Pharmacopoeia and Code of Ethics for practitioners registered under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) to award scholarships and stipends to the students of recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l) to collect fees or charges prescribed for admission to the examination held by the Board and for certificate, diploma or degree to be granted or conferred by the Board under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       to recommend to the Government any grant for a recognised Unani or Ayurvedic institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) to make arrangements for establishment of standard Unani and Ayurvedic colleges, hospitals and charitable dispensaries;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o) to make arrangements for establishment and operation of a Unani and Ayurvedic medical store for supplying medicines and accessories to the Unani and Ayurvedic hospitals and dispensaries; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p) to do such other acts and things as it may be empowered or required to do by this Ordinance or the rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Meetings of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Board shall meet at such time and place, and every meeting of the Board shall be summoned in such manner, as may be prescribed by regulations:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that until such regulations are made, the Chairman may summon a meeting of the Board at such time and place as he may deem expedient by notice addressed to each member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Chairman shall preside at every meeting of the Board, and in his absence, the members present shall elect a member from amongst themselves to preside.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Except as hereinafter provided, all questions at a meeting of the Board shall be decided by a majority of the votes of the members present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Four members of the Board shall form a quorum.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) At every meeting of the Board the Chairman for the time being shall, in addition to his vote as a member of the Board, have a second or casting vote in case of an equality of votes.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Officers of the Board and their terms and conditions of service</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) The Board shall, with the previous approval in writing of the Government, appoint a Registrar on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by rules.          (2) If the office of the Registrar is vacant or if the Registrar is unable to perform functions of his office on account of absence, illness or any other cause, the Board may, with the previous approval of the Government, appoint any officer of the Board to act as Registrar until a new Registrar is appointed or until the Registrar resumes the functions of his office, as the case may be.            (3) The Registrar shall be the secretary to the Board and shall exercise such powers and perform such duties as may be prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Board may appoint such officers and employees as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as it may deem fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Registrar may, in the event of an urgency, appoint, for the efficient performance of the functions of the Board, such employees as he considers necessary on the terms and conditions prescribed by regulations:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that every appointment under this sub section shall be reported to the Board forthwith and no such appointment shall continue beyond six months unless approved by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER III</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>TEACHING INSTITUTIONS AND EXAMINATIONS</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Recognition of institutions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) Any institution imparting or desiring to impart instruction in Unani or Ayurvedic system of medicine may apply for recognition under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) An application for recognition shall be addressed to the Registrar and shall contain full information in respect of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the constitution and personnel of the managing body of the institution;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the subject and courses in which it imparts or proposes to impart instruction;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the equipment possessed by the institution and the number of students for whom accommodation and other provision has been or is proposed to be made;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the strength and particulars of its staff, their salaries, qualifications and the research work to their credit;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the fees levied or proposed to be levied and the financial provision made for capital expenditure on buildings and equipment and for the continued maintenance and efficient working of the institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Registrar shall place the application before the Board, and the Board may direct the Registrar to call for any further information which it may consider necessary and may also direct a local enquiry to be made by competent person or persons authorised by it in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) After considering the report of such local enquiry, if any, and making such further enquiry as may appear to it to be necessary, the Board shall, subject to the approval of the Government, grant or refuse to grant recognition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) When recognition is granted to an institution under this section, the name of the institution shall be published by the Board in the official Gazette.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Maintenance of standard of efficiency</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) It shall be the duty of the Board to secure the maintenance of an adequate standard of efficiency in recognised institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) For the purpose of securing such standard, the Board may¬-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) from time to time call upon the recognised institutions to furnish such information and particulars as may be required by the Board to judge the standard of administration, education and the financial position of the institutions; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) arrange for annual inspection of the recognised institutions through an inspector or inspection team appointed by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Withdrawal of recognition</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) The Board when it thinks fit may, and when required to do so by the Government shall, make an enquiry whether any recognised institution should cease to be a recognised institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If, on making such an enquiry and after considering all such information and reports as are referred to in the preceding section and making such further enquiry as may appear to it to be necessary, the Board is satisfied that the teaching facilities provided or other arrangements made in this connection by a recognised institution are not such as to secure an adequate standard of efficiency for the practice of the system of medicine taught in the institution, it shall make an order withdrawing the recognition:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no order under this sub section shall be made unless the institution concerned has been given an opportunity to raise, within a specified time, the standard of teaching and examination to the satisfaction of the Board and the institution has, in the opinion of the Board, failed to do so.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Duration of courses</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The duration of diploma course in recognised institutions of Unani or Ayurvedic system of medicine shall be four years and the course shall include the subjects prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board may arrange for degree and other higher courses in Unani and Ayurvedic systems and the duration and subjects of such courses shall be as prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Qualifications for admission to institutions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. The minimum qualifications for admission to different courses in a recognised institution shall be as prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Qualifying examination</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. (1) A qualifying examination shall be held at least once in every year or for the purpose of granting a diploma conferring the right of registration under this Ordinance or for the purpose of granting a degree after completion of higher study leading to a degree.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The examination shall be held on the subjects prescribed by regulations and the right of appearing at the examinations shall be restricted to candidates who have undergone a course of study in such subjects in the prescribed manner at a recognised institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The examination shall be held under the control of an examining body to be appointed by the Board duly approved by the Government on annual basis.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) There shall be appointed a Controller of Examinations who shall act as Secretary to the examining body and, so long as the Controller of Examinations is not appointed, the Registrar shall discharge the duties of the Controller of Examinations as prescribed by regulations.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration how made</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. (1) Applications under sub section (1) of section 23 shall be received annually after the results of the examinations held under section 21 are declared.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Applications for registration under this Ordinance shall be made in such form and on payment of such fee as may be prescribed by rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board shall examine the applications received under this section and after making such enquiries as it thinks fit regarding the qualifications and length and nature of practice of the applicants and their professional efficiency direct the entry of the names to be made in the register in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registration of Unani and Ayurvedic practitioners in Category A)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. (1) Every person who passes the qualifying examination in the Unani or Ayurvedic system of medicine from a recognised institution may apply under section 22 for registration in Category A of the respective register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Unani and Ayurvedic institutions specified in the Schedule shall be recognised institutions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board may, with the approval of the Government, by notification in the official Gazette, include any foreign Unani or Ayurvedic institution in Part B of the Schedule.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration of Unani and Ayurvedic practitioners in Category B)</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. Any person who passes a written and practical examination to be held annually by the examining body to be appointed under sub section (3) of section 21 in the subjects containing basic principles of medicine, materia medica, medicine and practical diagnosis of the Unani or, as the case may be, Ayurvedic system of medicine may apply under section 22 for registration in category B of the Unani or, as the case may be, Ayurvedic register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Removal from register, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. The Board may direct that the name of a practitioner who has been convicted of a cognizable offence or who after due enquiry has been found guilty of misconduct shall be removed from the register, if the offence or misconduct in the opinion of the Board discloses moral turpitude such as to render him unfit to practise his profession:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no action shall be taken by the Board under this section unless the person convicted of the cognizable offence or found guilty of misconduct has been given a reasonable opportunity to show cause against the punishment proposed to be inflicted on him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cancellation or alteration of entries in register, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. The Board may, on its own motion or on information received from any person and after due enquiry and giving an opportunity to the person concerned of being heard, cancel or alter any entry in the register, if in the opinion of the Board the entry was made fraudulently or improperly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER IV</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE REGISTRAR</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Maintenance of register</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. (1) Subject to any general or special orders of the Board it shall be the duty of the Registrar to keep the register and to attend the meetings of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The register shall contain the name, residence, age and qualification of every practitioner registered under this Ordinance and the dates on which the qualifications were acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Registrar shall keep the register correct and up-to-date and shall, from time to time, enter therein any alteration in the address and qualifications of the practitioners and remove therefrom the names of the practitioners who die or whose names are directed to be removed in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) If the Registrar has reason to believe that any registered practitioner has ceased to practise or changed his permanent address without due intimation to him, he may write by registered post to such practitioner at the address as entered in the register to enquire whether he has ceased to practise or has changed his residence and if within six months no reply is received, the Registrar may remove the name of such practitioner from the register:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Board may, at any time on the application of the practitioner whose name is removed under this sub-section, order that the name of such practitioner be re-entered in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Publication of list</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. (1) The Registrar shall, in every third year on or before a date to be fixed by the Board, cause to be published a correct list of the names and qualifications of all practitioners for the time being entered in the register and the dates when such qualifications were acquired.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall be presumed that any person entered in such list is registered practitioner and that any person not so entered is not a registered practitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER V</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">RIGHTS, DUTIES AND LIABILITIES OF REGISTERED PRACTITIONERS</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Intimation of change of address</p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. Every registered practitioner shall inform the Registrar of any change of his permanent address.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Privileges of registered practitioners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">30. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force, every practitioner registered under section 23 shall be entitled-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to hold any appointment as physician or medical officer in any Unani or, as the case may be, Ayurvedic dispensary, hospital, infirmary or lying-in-hospital, if such dispensary, hospital, infirmary or lying-in-hospital is supported by or receives a grant from the Government or any local authority and treats patients according to the system of medicine or in any public establishment, body or institution practising such system;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to vote for the election of members to the Board; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to recover fees through Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A practitioner registered under section 24 shall be entitled to the privileges specified in clauses (b) and (c) of sub-section (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A registered practitioner shall abide by the Code of Ethics for Unani and Ayurvedic practitioners framed by the Board and approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER VI</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>OFFENCES, PENALTY AND PROCEDURE</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Offences and Penalties</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">31. Whoever contravenes the provisions of sub-section (3) of section 30 shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Persons not registered under Ordinance not to practise, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">32. (1) No person other than a practitioner registered under this Ordinance shall practise or hold himself out, whether directly or by implication, as practising the Unani or, as the case may be, Ayurvedic system of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes the provisions of sub-section (1) shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Colourable imitation of degrees</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">33. (1) No person other than a body or institution authorised under this Ordinance shall confer, grant or issue or holdout as entitled to confer, grant or issue a degree, diploma or certificate which purports to entitle the holder to practise the Unani or Ayurvedic system of medicine or which is identical with or is a colourable imitation of any degree, diploma or certificate granted by a body or institution so authorised.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever contravenes the provisions of this section shall be punishable with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand and if the person so contravening is an association, every member of such association who knowingly or wilfully authorise or permits the contravention shall be punishable with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition against use of title, description, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">34. (1) No person shall add to his name, title or description any letters or abbreviations which imply or are calculated to lead to the belief that he holds a degree, diploma or certificate as his qualification to practise the Unani or Ayurvedic system of medicine, unless he holds such degree, diploma or certificate and such degree, diploma or certificate-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         is recognised by any law for the time being in force in Bangladesh; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        has been conferred, granted or issued by a body or institution authorised under this Ordinance in this behalf; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       has been conferred, granted or issued by an authority empowered or recognised as competent by the Government to confer, grant or issue such degree, diploma or certificate.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, no Hakim or Vaid shall describe himself as a Doctor.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Whoever contravenes the provisions of this section shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to Taka one thousand, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Savings</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">35. Nothing in this chapter shall apply to any person-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        who limits his practice to dentistry; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        who being a nurse, midwife or health visitor and registered as such under any law for the time being in force, or a dai, attends on a case of labour; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        who being a technical assistant like JARRAH or KUHAL attends on a case under the direction and personal guidance of a registered practitioner of the Unani system of medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cognizance of offences, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">36. (1) No Court shall take cognizance of any offence under this Ordinance except on a complaint in writing by an officer empowered in this behalf by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No Court other than of a Magistrate of the first class shall try an offence under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER VII</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>SUPERSESSION OF THE BOARD</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Supersession of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">37. (1) If at any time it appears to the Government that the Board has failed to exercise or has exceeded or abused any of the powers conferred upon it by or under this Ordinance, the Government may, if it considers such failure, excess or abuse to be of serious character, notify the particulars thereof to the Board and if the Board fails to remedy such default, excess or abuse, within such time as may be fixed in this behalf, the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, supersede the Board for such period, not exceeding ninety days, as may be specified in the notification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the supersession of the Board under sub section (1)-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)  the persons holding office as Chairman and members of the Board shall cease to hold office; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)  all powers and functions of the Board shall, during period of supersession, be exercised and performed by such person or authority as the Government may appoint in this behalf, as if such person or authority were the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board shall be reconstituted in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance for the exercise and performance of its powers and functions on the expiry of the period specified in the notification under sub-section (1).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>CHAPTER VIII</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>MISCELLANEOUS</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Grants, aids and fees received by the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">38. All moneys received by the Board as fees shall be applied for the purposes of the Board in accordance with the rules made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Death of registered practitioners</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">39. Every person-in-charge of registration of deaths shall, on receiving notice of the death of a registered practitioner, forthwith transmit by post to the Registrar a certificate under his own hand of such death with the particulars of time and place of death and may charge from the Registrar the cost of such certificate and transmission as an expense of his office.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">40. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any person for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Ordinance or the rules or regulations made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">41. (1) The Government may, after consulting the Board, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules to carry out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the time and place at which and the manner in which elections shall be held;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the manner in which vacancies shall be filled;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the form of register and the particulars to be entered therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) fees chargeable for the registration, alteration in the register regarding additional qualifications and alteration of other entries in the register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the purposes for which the fees received by the Board shall be applied.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">42. The Board may, with the approval in writing of the Government, make regulations not inconsistent with this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder for the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) courses of study for training and qualifying examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) languages in which examinations shall be conducted and instruction given;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) admission of students to recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the conditions under which candidates shall be admitted to different courses and the qualifying and other examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the conditions of appointment of examiners and conduct of examinations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the conditions for the appointment of teachers in recognised institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the requirements for the recognition of teaching institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) the time and place at which the Board shall hold its meetings;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) such other matters as may be necessary for the exercise of powers and performance of functions to be exercised or performed by the Board under this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal and Savings</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">43. (1) The Unani, Ayurvedic and Homoeopathic Practitioners Act 1965 (II of 1965), hereinafter referred to as the said Act, in so far as it relates to the Board of Unani and Ayurvedic Systems of Medicine established thereunder, hereinafter referred to as the defunct Board, is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the repeal of the said Act,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges, and all properties, movable and immovable, cash and bank balances and fund of the defunct Board in Bangladesh and all other interests and rights in, or arising out of, such property shall stand transferred to, and vested in, the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all debts, liabilities and obligations of the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall be the debts, liabilities and obligation of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall be deemed to have been instituted by or against the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all officers and employees of the defunct Board in Bangladesh shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or agreement or in the terms and conditions of service, stand transferred to the Board and shall be deemed to be officers and other employees of the Board appointed by it on the same terms and conditions of service as were applicable to them in the defunct Board unless such terms and conditions are altered, not being to their disadvantage, by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) every Unani and Ayurvedic practitioner registered under the said Act shall be deemed to be registered under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
628	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH VETERINARY PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH VETERINARY PRACTITIONERS ORDINANCE, 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXX OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[7th September, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make provision for the regulation, control and registration of Veterinary practitioners in Bangladesh and for the constitution of a Veterinary Council and for matters connected therewith.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provision for the regulation, control and registration of veterinary practitioners in Bangladesh and for the constitution of a Veterinary Council and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Veterinary Practitioners Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Council” means the Bangladesh Veterinary Council constituted under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “member” means a member of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “Prescribed” means prescribed by regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “President” means the President of the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “recognised Veterinary qualification” means any of the veterinary qualification included in the schedule;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “register” means the register of veterinary practitioners maintained under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        “registered veterinary practitioners” means a person whose name is for the time being entered in the register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        “Registrar” means the person appointed as Registrar by the Council; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         “Veterinary Institution” means any Institution which trains for, or grants, or both trains for and grants, degrees, diplomas or licence in Veterinary Science</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Constitution of the Council</p><p style="text-align: justify;">.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) There shall be constituted a Council which shall consist of the following members, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Director of Livestock Services, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        one Registered Veterinary Practitioner from each of the Administrative Divisions of Bangladesh, to be elected in the manner prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the President shall have power to nominate a registered veterinary practitioner if no such practitioner is elected from any division under this clause;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        one Registered Veterinary Practitioner, to be nominated by the Bangladesh Agricultural University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the Dean of the Faculty of Veterinary Science of the Bangladesh Agricultural University, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        the President of the Bangladesh Veterinary Association, ex-officio;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         one member, belonging to the legal profession, to be nominated by the Chief Justice of Bangladesh; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        one member of the defence services possessing recognised veterinary qualification, to be nominated by the Bangladesh Army:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that for the constitution of the Council for the first time, all the members, other than the ex-officio members, shall be appointed by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The members shall elect a President from amongst themselves in such manner as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that for the constitution of the Council for the first time, the President shall be appointed by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Incorporation of the Council</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. The Council shall be a body corporate by the name of the Bangladesh Veterinary Council, having perpetual succession and common seal with power to acquire and hold property, both movable and immovable and to contract, and shall, by the said name, sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Term of office</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The President shall hold office for a term not exceeding four years and not extending beyond the expiry of his term as member, and shall be eligible for re-election.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The President shall be deemed to have vacated office on the day the Council holds its meeting after its re-constitution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The President may resign his office by notice in writing addressed to the Government and shall be deemed to have vacated office on such resignation being accepted by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A member, other than an ex-officio member, shall hold office for a term of four years from the date of his nomination or, as the case may be, election, or until his successor has been nominated or elected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) A member shall be eligible for re-election or, as the case may be, re-nomination.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) A member, other than an ex-officio member shall vacate office if he-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        resigns his office by notice in writing addressed to the President and the resignation is accepted by the President;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        fails to attend three consecutive meetings of the Council without leave of absence granted by the Council;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        remains out of Bangladesh for a continuous period exceeding one and a half year;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        ceases to represent the particular interest for which he was elected or, as the case may be, nominated.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) Any casual vacancy in the office of member, including the President caused by death, resignation, removal or otherwise shall be filled by election or, as the case may be, nomination and the person so elected or nominated shall hold office for the unexpired period of the term of office of his predecessor.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Meeting of the Council</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) The Council shall meet at least twice in a year at such time and place, and shall be summoned in such manner, as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that until regulations are made, the President may call a meeting of the Council by sending notice to each member.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To constitute a quorum at a meeting of the Council not less than five members shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All meetings of the Council shall be presided by the President and in his absence, by a member who is a Registered Veterinary Practitioner elected by the members present at the meeting.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) All questions at a meeting of the Council shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting, and in the case of an equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a second or casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) No act done by the Council shall be invalid merely on the ground of the existence of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appointment of officers, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The Council shall appoint a Registrar and such other officers and employees as it may consider necessary on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Registrar shall act as Secretary to the Council and shall, until another person is appointed as treasurer, also act as treasurer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All persons appointed under this section shall be deemed to be public servants within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code (Act XLV of 1860).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Fund of the Council</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) There shall be a fund of the Council to which shall be credited-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        grants and loans from the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b         registration fees and other fees;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        income from investments and properties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        aids and grants, if any, received from foreign countries with the prior approval of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The fund of the Council shall be utilised by the Council to meet the charges in connection with the functions of the Council and payment of salaries and allowances to its officers and employees.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The fund of the Council shall be kept in such bank or banks as may be approved by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Council may invest its funds in such securities as may be approved by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Accounts and audit</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) The Council shall maintain regular accounts of all moneys received and expended by it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts shall be audited every year by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of Bangladesh, hereinafter in this section referred to as the Auditor-General, in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of an audit under sub-section (2), the Auditor-General or any person authorised by him in this behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash, securities and other properties of the Council and may examine the President or any member officer or employee of the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Auditor-General shall, as soon as possible after the completion of the audit, send to the Council his audit report and the Council shall forward it, with its comments thereon, to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Council shall take steps forthwith to remedy any defects or irregularities pointed out in the audit report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Register of Veterinary Practitioner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The Council shall, as soon as may be after its constitution, arrange for the registration of veterinary practitioners and, for that purpose, shall, by notification in the official Gazette and publishing notice in at least two daily newspapers of wide circulation, one in the Bengali Language and the other in the English Language, appoint a date on or before which applications for registration of names shall be made by veterinary practitioners possessing recognised veterinary qualification.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The names and addresses, the recognised veterinary qualification together with the dates on which such qualifications were acquired and the dates of registration of all veterinary practitioners registered under this Ordinance shall be entered in a register to be maintained by the Council for the purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Custody and maintenance of register</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) The Registrar shall maintain the register in such from and in such manner as may be prescribed and shall make form time to time such entries, corrections, alterations and modifications in the entries therein as may be necessary or as may be directed by the Council.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Registrar may, for the purpose of carrying out his duties imposed under sub-section (1), call for any information he may require from any registered veterinary practitioner or a veterinary practitioner applying for registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Persons entitled to be registered</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) Every person possessing a recognised veterinary qualification may, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance and on payment of such fees as may be prescribed, apply to the Council to have his name entered in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every person making an application under sub-section (1) shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        satisfy the Council that he is in possession of a recognised veterinary qualification;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        specify in his application the date on which he acquired the qualification which entitles him to claim registration; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        furnish such other information as the Council may require for the purpose of registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Registration</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Council may on being satisfied that a person applying for registration possesses a recognised veterinary qualification and has paid the prescribed fee, allow the application and direct the Registrar to enter his name in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Registrar shall, on the registration of the person's name, give him a certificate of registration signed by him and countersigned by the President.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Council may after giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard, refuse to permit the registration, or cancel the registration of the name of any person,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) who has been convicted by any Court for any offence involving moral turpitude;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        whom the Council, after due enquiry, finds guilty of infamous conduct in his professional capacity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Council may, on its own motion or upon an application made to it by any person, direct, after giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        for the purpose of rectification of any error, amendment or any entry in the register;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        cancellation of any registration which has been fraudulently made or effected.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) Where the name of a registered veterinary practitioner is removed for any reason under this Ordinance, the Council may, on its own motion or upon an application made to it by the concerned veterinary practitioner, allow the name of the veterinary practitioner to be registered again in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) The Registrar shall by letter sent by registered post inform the veterinary practitioner of his registration, any amendment or cancellation of his registration or restoration of his name in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) If any person whose name is entered in the register obtains any recognised veterinary qualification other than the qualification in respect of which his name has been registered, he shall, on payment of such fee as may be prescribed, be entitled to have such additional qualification entered against his name in the register either in substitution of or in addition to, any entry previously made.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appeal</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. If any person is dissatisfied with the decision of the Council refusing or cancelling the registration of his name or directing the correction or cancellation of any entry in the register, he may, at any time within sixty days from the date of such decision and on payment of such fees as may be prescribed, prefer an appeal to the Government and the decision of the Government shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Amendment of the Schedule</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. The Government, after consultation with the Council, may, if it thinks fit, by notification in the official Gazette amend the schedule so as to include therein, or omit therefrom, any veterinary qualification granted by any veterinary institution.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to call for information, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The Council shall have power to call on the authorities of any veterinary institution in Bangladesh to furnish such particulars as the Council may require of any courses of study and examinations to be undergone in order to obtain the degree, diploma or licence granted by that veterinary institution, as to the minimum age at which such courses of study can be undertaken, examinations required to be undergone prior to such degree, diploma or licence being granted, and generally as to the requisites for obtaining such degree, diploma or licence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Notice of deaths and removal of names from register</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. On receipt of any reliable information regarding the death of any registered veterinary practitioner, the Registrar shall, after making such enquiry as he deems fit, remove the name of the deceased from the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Publication of and presumption as to entries in the list of registered veterinary practitioners</p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. (1) The Registrar shall once in every four years, on or before such date as may be determined by the Council, cause to be published in the official Gazette a list in alphabetical order the names of all persons who are registered in the register together with their addresses and recognised veterinary qualification and the date on which such qualifications were obtained.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Registrar shall also cause to be published in the official Gazette in the month of January every year an annual supplement to the list published under sub-section (1) showing therein the additions, alternations or corrections made in the entries in the register during the preceding year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Register shall be deemed to be a public document within the meaning of the Evidence Act, 1872 (I of 1872).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Responsibility of Registered Veterinary Practitioner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) Every registered veterinary practitioner shall inform the Council any change of his address within sixty days of such change and, on receipt of the information, the Registrar shall make the necessary corrections in the register.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No registered veterinary practitioner shall use or publish in any way whatsoever any name, title, description or symbol indicating or calculated to lead persons to infer that he possesses any recognised veterinary qualification higher than that he or other professional qualification unless the same has been conferred upon him by a legally constituted authority within or outside Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Privileges of registered veterinary practitioner</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any other law for the time being in force, no one, other than a registered veterinary practitioner, shall be competent to hold any veterinary appointment in a veterinary institution, hospital, dispensary or abattoir maintained or aided by the Government or any local authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, no certificate required by any such law to be signed by a veterinary practitioner shall be valid unless it is signed by a registered veterinary practitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) No person shall be entitled to recover any fee or nichargeany Court for any veterinary advice or attendance, or for the performance of any operation, or for any medicine supplied, unless he shall prove upon the trial that he is a duly registered veterinary practitioner.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Persons not registered under the Ordinance not to practise</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. (1) Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in any other law for the time being in force, no one, other than a registered veterinary practitioner, shall practise, or hold himself out as practising, the veterinary medicine or surgery.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever, after the date fixed in this behalf by notification in the official Gazette by the Council, contravenes the provision of sub-section (1) shall be punishable with fine which may extend to Taka five hundred;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The provisions of sub-section (1) shall not apply to any person who performs any of the following acts, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        Rendering to any animal first aid for the purpose of saving life or relieving pain;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        destruction of any animal by painless method;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        castration of any animal or caponising of any poultry or bird;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        docking of the cattle or dog before its eyes are open;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        amputation of the claws of a dog before its eyes are open;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         inoculation or vaccination of any animal, poultry or bird</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Proceedings in inquiries</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. For the purpose of any enquiry under this Ordinance, the Council shall be deemed to be a Court within the meaning of Evidence Act, 1872 and shall exercise all the powers of a Commissioner appointed under the Public Servant's (Inquiries) Act, 1850 (XXXVII of 1850).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Indemnity</p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall be against the Council or any officer or employee thereof for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to make regulations</p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. The Council may, with the previous approval of the Government, make regulations for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
629	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BANGLADESH WOMEN’S REHABILITATION AND WELFARE FOUNDATION (REPEAL) ORDINANCE, 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BANGLADESH WOMEN’S REHABILITATION AND WELFARE FOUNDATION (REPEAL) ORDINANCE, 1984</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXVII OF 1984).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[4th June, 1984]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal the Bangladesh Women’s Rehabilitation and Welfare Foundation Act, 1974.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal the Bangladesh Women’s Rehabilitation and Welfare Foundation Act, 1974 (LI of 1974), and to provide for matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Bangladesh Women's Rehabilitation and Welfare Foundation (Repeal) Ordinance, 1984.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Repeal of Act LI of 1974</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) The Bangladesh Women's Rehabilitation and Welfare Foundation Act, 1974 (LI of 1974), hereinafter referred to as the said Act, is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the repeal of the said Act,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the Bangladesh Women's Rehabilitation and Welfare Foundation, hereinafter referred to as the said Foundation, established under the said Act, shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all property, movable and immovable, including lands, buildings, cash balances, reserve funds, investments and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such property and all books of accounts, registers, records, and all other documents of the said Foundation shall stand transferred to, and vest in, the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all debts and liabilities incurred, all obligations undertaken, all contracts entered into and all agreements made by or with the said Foundation and subsisting or having effect immediately before such repeal shall be deemed to have been incurred, undertaken or entered into or made by or with the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said Foundation and pending immediately before such repeal shall be deemed to have been instituted by or against the Government and may be continued and proceeded with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) all officers and other employees of the said foundation shall stand transferred to the Government and shall hold office or service under the Government under the same terms and conditions as were applicable to them before their transfer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in any terms and conditions of service, the Government may alter the terms and conditions of service of any officer or other employee transferred under sub-section (2), and if such alteration is not acceptable to an officer or employee, the Government may terminate his employment by giving him compensation equivalent to three months' pay in case of a permanent officer or employee or one month's pay in case of a temporary officer or employee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Explanation.-The compensation to an officer or other employee under sub-section (3) shall be in addition to any pension, gratuity or other benefit to which the officer or employee may be entitled under the terms and conditions of his service.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Government may, for the purpose of removing any difficulty in relation to the transfer and other matters specified in sub-section (2), make such orders as it may consider expedient and any such order shall be deemed to be and given effect to as part of the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
630	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE BREAST-MILK SUBSTITUTES (REGULATION OF MARKETING) ORDINANCE 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE BREAST-MILK SUBSTITUTES (REGULATION OF MARKETING) ORDINANCE, 1984</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO XXXIII OF 1984).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[24th May, 1984]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to promote breast-feeding by regulating the marketing of breast-milk substitutes.WHEREAS it is expedient to promote breast-feeding by regulating the marketing of breast-milk substitutes and to provide for matters incidental thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>commencement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Breast-Milk Substitutes (Regulation of Marketing) Ordinance 1984.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)“breast-milk substitute” means any food represented as a partial or total substitute for breast-milk and includes a complementary food;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1[ (aa) “breast-milk supplement or weaning food” means any food manufactured or locally prepared to be used as a complement to breast-milk or infant formula, when either becomes insufficient to satisfy the nutritional requirements of infants;]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)“complementary food” means any food represented as a complement to breast-milk or 2[ infant formula, and includes any breast-milk supplement or weaning food];</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “infant formula” means a breast-milk substitute formulated to satisfy the normal nutritional requirements of infants up to six months of age;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “protected person” means a pregnant woman, a mother of an infant whose apparent age is not more than two years, and a person who is the husband of such woman or mother or father of such child; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition against certain advertisement regarding breast-milk substitutes</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. No person shall make, exhibit, distribute, circulate, display or publish any advertisement-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) promoting the use of any breast-milk substitute; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) implying or designed to create the belief or impression that breast-milk substitute feeding is equivalent or superior to breast-milk feeding.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Promotion of breast-milk substitute prohibited</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. No person shall promote any breast-milk substitute either by advertisement or by offering or giving any gift, prize, discount coupon, or other free item or by any other means.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration of breast-milk substitutes</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ 4A. (1) From the date as may be notified by the Government in the official Gazette, no breast-milk substitute of any kind shall be imported, distributed, marketed, stored, sold, offered for sale or be locally manufactured for sale unless it is registered under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A breast-milk substitute shall be registered in such manner and on payment of such fees as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A registration granted under this section shall be valid for a period of three years and may be cancelled before the expiry of that period in such manner as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Registration of a breast-milk substitute shall be published in the official Gazette.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Container and labeling</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) No breast-milk substitute shall be marketed unless-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) it is put in a sealed and hermetically closed container;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) an easily readable and understandable message in Bangla is printed on a conspicuous part of its container to the effect that nothing is substitute for or equivalent or superior to breast-milk;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) clear instructions on the proper method of its preparation and information regarding its composition are printed on the container or in a literature kept inside the container; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) 4[ its registration number and the dates] of its manufacture and the expiry of its usefulness are printed on the container.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Neither the container nor any literature kept inside the container shall have any picture of infant or such other picture or writing which may idealist the use of any breast-milk substitute.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Advisory Committee</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) The Government may appoint an Advisory Committee consisting of a Chairman and not more than such number of other members as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5[ (2) The Advisory Committee shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) advise the Government on the proper observation of the International Code of Marketing of Breast-Milk Substitutes;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) perform such other functions relating to the purpose of this Ordinance as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalties</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. Whoever contravenes any of the provisions of sections 3, 4 and 5 of this Ordinance shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine which may extend to five thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Offences by Companies</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) If the person contravening any of the provisions of this Ordinance is a company, every person who at the time the offence has been committed was in charge of, and was responsible to, the company for the conduct of the business of the company as well as the company, shall be deemed to be guilty of the contravention and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing contained in this sub-section shall render any such person liable to any punishment provided in this Ordinance if he proves that the offence was committed without his knowledge or that he exercised all due diligence to prevent the commission of such offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where any offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to, any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other officer of the company, such director, manger, secretary or other officer shall also be deemed to be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>:For the purposes of this section-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “company” means any body corporate and includes a firm or other association of individual, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “director”, in relation to a firm, means a partner in the firm.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cognizance of offence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No Court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under this Ordinance except upon a report in writing made by any officer authorised by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the authorised officer for anything which is in good faith done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>: In this section, “authorised officer” means an officer authorised by the Government in writing to perform all or any of the functions under this Ordinance and includes any officer authorised by such authorised Officer.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11.
