635	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE DISTRICTS (EXTENSION TO THE CHITTAGONG HILL-TRACTS) ORDINANCE 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content">                        						THE DISTRICTS (EXTENSION TO THE CHITTAGONG HILL-TRACTS) ORDINANCE 1984(ORDINANCE NO LXXI OF 1984).[5th December, 1984]An Ordinance to extend the Districts Act 1836, to the Chittagong Hill-tracts.WHEREAS it is expedient to extend the Districts Act 1836 (XXI of 1836), to the Chittagong Hill-tracts; NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers, enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-<strong>Commencement</strong>1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Districts (Extension to the Chittagong Hill-tracts) Ordinance, 1984.(2) It shall be deemed to have come into force on the 18th April, 1981.<strong>Definition</strong>2. In this Ordinance, the expression “Chittagong Hill-tracts” means the area known by that name as existing on the first day of January, 1936.Application of Act XXI of 1836 to the Chittagong Hill-tracts3. The Districts Act, 1836 (XXI of 1836), shall apply to the Chittagong Hill-tracts.<strong>Validation</strong>4. The new districts of Bandarban and Khagrachari created in the Chittagong Hill-tracts under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898), before the commencement of this Ordinance shall be deemed to have been created under the Districts Act, 1836 (XXI of 1836).<strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs                      </div></div>
636	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE DRUGS (CONTROL) ORDINANCE 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. VIII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[12th June, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to control manufacture, import, distribution and sale of drugs.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to control manufacture, import, distribution and sale of drugs;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Drugs (Control) Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Application of other Laws, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The provisions of this Ordinance shall be in addition to, and not in derrogation of, the Drugs Act, 1940 (XXIII of 1940), and any other law for the time being in force and shall have effect notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in that Act or in any such law or in any contract, agreement or document.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Act” means the Drugs Act 1940 (XXIII of 1940);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “Committee” means the Drugs Control Committee constituted under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “Council” means the National Drugs Advisory Council constituted under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “Drug” shall have the same meaning as in the Act and shall also include any substance exclusively used or prepared for use in accordance with the ayurvedic, unani and homeopathic or biochemic system of medicine;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “Schedule” means Schedule to this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        Words and expressions used but not defined in this Ordinance shall have the same meaning as in the Act.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Drug Control Committee</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Government shall constitute a Drug Control Committee consisting of a Chairman and such other members as it may appoint from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Committee shall perform such functions as are specified in this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration of Medicines</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) No medicine of any kind shall be manufactured for sale or be imported, distributed 1[ , stocked, exhibited or sold] unless it is registered with the licensing authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 (1A) For the purpose of registration of Homeopathic and Biochemic medicines the licensing authority shall follow the quality standards set out in the Homeopathic and Biochemic pharmacopoeias accepted in such country as the Government may by notification in the official Gazette, specified.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The licensing authority shall not register a medicine unless such registration is recommended by the Committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A registration shall be granted on such conditions as may be specified by the licensing authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A registration shall, unless cancelled earlier, be valid for a period of five years.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cancellation or suspension of registration</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) The licensing authority may cancel the registration of any medicine if such cancellation is recommended by the Committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Committee shall evaluate every medicine registered before the commencement of this Ordinance and every medicine that may be manufactured or imported after such commencement in order to determine its safety, efficacy and usefulness.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3)        If on such evaluation the Committee finds that any such medicine is not safe, efficacious or useful, it may recommend to the licensing authority cancellation of registration of the medicine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The licensing authority may, if it is satisfied that a medicine is sub-standard, suspend the registration of such medicine till he is satisfied that the medicine has attained its standard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appeal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3[ 6A. (1) Whoever is aggrieved by an order or decision of the licensing authority under sections 5 and 6 may, within one month from the date of making of the order or decision, prefer an appeal to the Appellate Authority appointed under sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government shall, for the purpose of this section, appoint an Appellate Authority consisting of a Chairman and such number of other members as it may think fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Appellate Authority shall give its decision on an appeal after giving the parties concerned an opportunity of being heard.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The decision of the Appellate Authority shall be final and shall be binding upon the parties and shall not be called in question before any Court or authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fees for registration</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. No registration of a medicine shall be granted unless a fee to be determined by the Government is paid at the time of application for registration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Prohibition of Manufacture, etc, of certain medicines</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) On the commencement of this Ordinance, the registration or licence in respect of all medicines mentioned in the Schedules shall stand cancelled, and no such medicine shall, subject to the provisions of sub-section (2), be manufactured, imported, distributed 4[ , stocked, exhibited or sold] after such commencement.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1),-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the medicines specified in Schedule I shall be destroyed within three months from the date of commencement of this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the medicines specified in Schedule II may be manufactured or sold for a period of 5[ twelve months] from the date of commencement of this Ordinance and thereafter their manufacture 6[ , stock, exhibition and sale] shall be permitted only if they are registered after change in their formulation in accordance with the direction of the licensing authority;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the medicines specified in Schedule III may be manufactured, imported, distributed and sold for a period of 7[ eighteen months] after the commencement of this Ordinance, and thereafter there shall not be any manufacture, import, distribution 8[ , stock, exhibition or sale] of such medicines 9 ;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) the medicines specified in Schedule IV may be manufactured, distributed and sold for a period of eighteen months after the commencement of this Ordinance, and thereafter their manufacture, distribution 10[ , stock, exhibition and sale] shall be permitted only if they are registered again with the licensing authority:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no fresh import of raw materials for the manufacture of the medicines specified in Schedule III and Schedule IV shall be permitted.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Restriction on import of certain pharmaceutical raw material</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) No pharmaceutical raw material necessary for the manufacture of any medicine specified in any of the Schedules shall be imported.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No drug 11[ , semi-finished bulk drug] or pharmaceutical raw material shall be imported except with the prior approval of the licensing authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The licensing authority may award an approval under sub-section (2) on such conditions as it deems fit to specify 12[ :</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that in case of awarding approval to import any finished medicine, such medicine shall be registered for sale under the same brand name in any of the countries specified under sub-section (1A) of section 5.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Manufacture of drugs under licensing agreement etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13 10. Subject to the approval of the licensing authority,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) a foreign manufacturer may be allowed to manufacturer any drug under licensing agreement with any manufacturer in Bangladesh if the drug is its research product and is registered under the same brand name in any of the countries specified under sub-section (1A) of section 5;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) a manufacturer in Bangladesh may be allowed to manufacture any drug under any written contract with any pharmaceutical manufacturing plant in Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fixation of price of drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, fix the maximum price at which any medicine may be sold.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may by notification in the official Gazette, fix the maximum price at which any pharmaceutical raw material may be imported or sold.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Review of certain licensing agreement with foreign concerns</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) The Government may, review any licensing agreement between a Bangladeshi concern and a foreign concern for manufacture of any drug in Bangladesh in order to find out if it contains any provision against the national interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If on such review the Government finds that any such provision of any such agreement is against the national interest, it may direct the concerns to modify such provision.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) If any such concern fails to comply with the direction given under sub-section (2) the manufacturing licence of such concern may be cancelled by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Employment of 14[ ]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. <strong>15 (1) No person shall manufacture</strong>-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) any allopathic drug except under the personal supervision of two personnel, out of whom one shall be a pharmacist registered in Register “A” of the Pharmacy Council of Bangladesh and another shall be a person having the following academic qualification from any university recognised by the Government-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) Master's degree or Bachelor degree with Honours (4 years curricula) in Chemistry, Biochemistry, Applied Chemistry, Microbiology, Pharmacology or Genetic Engineering; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) Bachelor degree in Pharmacy, Medicine or Chemical Engineering;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) any Unani, Ayurvedic or Homeopathic or Biochemic system of medicine or other herbal drug except under the personal supervision of two whole time employees of the relevant manufacturing plant or unit, out of whom one shall be a person having degree or diploma in the field of respective system of medicine from any university or institution recognised by the Government with at least one year's practical experience in the manufacture and quality control of drugs of the relevant system and another shall be a person having Bachelor degree in Pharmacy or Bachelor degree with Honours (4 years curricula) in Chemistry, Botany, Applied Chemistry, Biochemistry, with specialisation in Phytochemistry or Pharmacognosy, from any university recognised by the Government with at least one year's practical experience in the manufacture and quality control of drugs of the relevant system.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No person, being a retailer, shall sell any drug without the personal supervision of a pharmacist registered in any Register of the Pharmacy Council of Bangladesh:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that this provision shall not apply to the retail sale of any drug under the ayurvedic, unani, or homeopathic or biochemic 16[ system of medicine or herbal drugs].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Control of advertisement and claims in respect of drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. No person shall publish or take any part in the publication of any advertisement which relates to the use of any drug or contains any claim in respect of therapics or treatment without the prior approval of the licensing authority.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>- “Advertisement” includes any notice, circular or other document displayed on or in any public place or public transport or published in any newspaper or periodical and any announcement made orally or by any means of producing or transmitting light or sound and any trade circular, insert and level.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prescription of unregistered medicine prohibited</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17) 14A. (1) No Physician shall prescribe for any patient any medicine which is not registered under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Nothing in this section shall apply to the prescription of any drug which is-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        manufactured in a foreign country after testing its efficacy and usefulness;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        imported with the permission of the licensing authority for the purpose of examination, test or analysis or for personal use.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Good practices in the manufacture and quality control of drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) Every manufacturer of drugs shall follow the good practices in the manufacture and quality contol of drugs recommended by the World Health Organisation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any manufacturer does not follow such good practices his manufactured licence may be cancelled or suspended.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for manufacture, etc, of certain drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. Whoever manufactures, imports, distributes 18[ , stocks, exhibits or sells]-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        any medicine which is not registered under this Ordinance, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        any medicine in contravention of the provisions of section 8, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        any drug which is adulterated 19[ , misbranded, spurious or imitated],</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine which may extend to two lakh Taka, or with both, and any implements used in the manufacture or sale of such medicine or drug may, by order of the Drug Court, be forfeited to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalty for manufacture, 20[ stock or sale] of sub-standard drugs</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. Whoever manufactures 21[ , stocks or sells] any sub-standard drug shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine which may extend to one lakh Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for unauthorised import of drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. Whoever imports any drug or pharmaceutical raw material without the prior approval of the licensing authority shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to fifty thousand Taka, or with both and such drug or raw material may, by order of the Drug Court, be forfeited to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Penalty for sale of medicine or import or sale of pharmaceutical raw material at a higher price</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. Whoever sells any medicine or imports or sells any pharmaceutical raw material at a price higher than the maximum price fixed by the Government under section 11 shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for theft, etc, of Government drugs</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. Whoever commits theft in respect of any drug in any Government store, hospital, clinic or health centre or sells any such drug or keeps in his possession any such drug for sale shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine which may extend to two lakh Taka or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for illegal advertisement and claims</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22) 21. Whoever contravenes the provision of section 14 shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine which may extend to two lakh Taka, or with both.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Offences by companies</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23) 21A. (1) Where an offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company, every person who at the time the offence has been committed, was in charge of, and was responsible to, the company for the conduct of the business of the company, as well as the company, shall be deemed to be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that nothing contained in this sub-section shall render any such person liable to any punishment provided in this Ordinance if he proves that the offence has been committed without his knowledge or that he exercised all due diligence to prevent the commission of such offence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), where any offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a company and it is proved that the offence has been committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to, any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other officer of the company, such director, manager, secretary or other officer shall also to be deemed to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation.- For the purposes of this section</strong>,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “company” means any body corporate and includes a firm or other association of individual, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “director”, in relation to a firm, means partner in the firm.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Cognizance of offences</p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898),-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        an offence punishable under this Ordinance shall be non-cognizable;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        no Court other than a Drug Court shall try an offence punishable under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        no Drug Court shall take cognizance of an offence punishable under this Ordinance except on a report in writing made by the licensing authority or an officer authorised by him in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Drug Courts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette establish as many Drug Courts as it considers necessary and where it establishes more than one Drug Court, shall specify in the notification the territorial limits within which each one of them shall exercise jurisdiction under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A Drug Court shall consist of a person who is or has been a Sessions Judge and he shall be appointed by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A Drug Court shall sit at such place as the Government may direct.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A Drug Court may pass any sentence authorised by this Ordinance and shall have all the powers conferred by the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898), on a Court of Session exercising original jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) A Drug Court shall not, merely by reason of a change in its composition, be bound to recall and rehear any witness who has given evidence, and may act on the evidence already recorded by or produced before it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) A Drug Court shall, in all matters with respect to which no procedure has been prescribed by this Ordinance, follow the procedure prescribed by the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898), for the trial of summons cases by Magistrates.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(7) A Drug Court may, on application in this behalf being made by the prosecution, try an offence under this Ordinance summarily in accordance with the provisions contained in sections 262 to 265 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(8) An appeal from the judgment of a Drug Court shall lie to the High Court Division.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>National Drug Advisory Council</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. (1) The Government shall constitute a National Drug Advisory Council consisting of a Chairman and such other members as it may appoint from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Council shall advise the Government on-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        measures to be adopted for the implementation of the national drug policy that may be adopted by the Government from time to time;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        measures for the promotion of local pharmaceutical industries and production and supply of essential drugs for meeting the needs of the country;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        matters relating to the import of drugs and pharmaceutical raw materials;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        measures for the co-ordination of the activities of the various Ministries, agencies and persons dealing with manufacture, import, distribution and sale of drugs.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The commas and the words “, stocked, exhibited or sold” were substituted for the words “or sold” by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2 Sub-section (1A) was inserted by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3 Section 6A was inserted by section 3 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4 The commas and the words “, stocked, exhibited or sold” were substituted for the words “or sold” by section 4 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5 The words “twelve months” were substituted for the words “six months” by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XXVIII of 1982)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6 The commas and the words “, stock, exhibition and sale” were substituted for the words “and sale” by section 4 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7 The words “eighteen months” were substituted for the words “nine months” by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XXVIII of 1982)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8 The commas and the words “, stock, exhibition or sale” were substituted for the words “or sale” by section 4 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9 The semi-colon (;) was substituted for the full-stop (.) and clause (d) was added thereafter by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982 (Ordinance No. XXVIII of 1982)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">10 The commas and the words “, stock, exhibition and sale” were substituted for the words “and sale” by section 4 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11 The comma and the words “, semi-finished bulk drug” were inserted by section 3 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12 The colon (:) was substituted for the full-stop (.) and thereafter the proviso was added by section 3 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">13 Section 10 was substituted by section 4 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">14 The commas and the words “, stocked, exhibited or sold” were substituted for the words “or sold” by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">15 Sub-section (1) was substituted by section 5 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">16 The words “system of medicine or herbal drugs” were substituted for the words “system of medicine” by section 5 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: stocks, exhibits or sells” were substituted for the words “or sells” by section 6 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">19 The commas and words “, misbranded, spurious or imitated” were substituted for the words “or spurious” by section 6 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">20 Sub-section (1A) was inserted by section 2 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Act, 2006 (Act No. IV of 2006)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">21 The comma and the words “, stocks or sells” were substituted for the words “or sell” by section 7 of the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: the Drugs (Control) (Amendment) Ordinance, 1984 (Ordinance No. XLIII of 1984)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
637	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE EMIGRATION ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE EMIGRATION ORDINANCE, 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXIX OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[7th September, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal and, with certain amendments, re-enact the Emigration Act, 1922.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal and, with certain amendments, re-enact the Emigration Act, 1922 (VII of 1922), for the purposes hereinafter appearing;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong> Application and commencement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Emigration Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It applies to all citizens of Bangladesh wherever they may be.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint; and different dates may be appointed for different provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “citizen” means a citizen of the People's Republic of Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “demand” means any requirement or offer for employment of workers by a foreign or Bangladeshi employer, having any project or contract or establishment abroad, which is supported by visa instructions or work permit from the competent Government authority of the country of employment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “depart” and “departure” means the departure out of Bangladesh of any person for employment by any foreign or Bangladeshi employer or for self-employment by any means;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “dependent” means any woman or child who is related to an emigrant and any aged or incapacitated relative of an emigrant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “emigrant” means any person who emigrates or is assisted to emigrate or has emigrated under this Ordinance and includes any dependent of an emigrant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “emigrate” and “emigration” means the departure by sea, air or land out of Bangladesh of any person for the purpose or with the intention of working for wages or engaging in any trade, profession or calling in any country beyond the limits of Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        “licence” means a document issued by the Government authorising a person or an entity to operate as recruiting agent for employment abroad;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        “newspaper” shall have the same meaning as defined in the Printing Presses and Publications (Declaration and Registration) Act, 1973 (XXIII of 1973);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         “overseas employment” means employment of a citizen outside Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        “recruiting agent” means a person licensed under section 10;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         “recruit” means issuing a letter of appointment signing contracts for employment abroad by a foreign or Bangladeshi employer, making preliminary arrangements for selecting persons for employment abroad through advertisement, publicity, letter, preparation of panel, verbally or in writing, and any other steps towards furtherance of the objectives of the employment of a citizen abroad;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       “Registrar” means a Registrar of Emigrants appointed under this Ordinance; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        “rules” means rules made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In case of any doubt or dispute arising otherwise than in the course of any proceedings, as to whether a person is an emigrant within the meaning of this Ordinance, the question shall be determined by the Government and such determination shall be final.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appointment of Registrar of Emigrants</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) The Government may appoint a person to be a Registrar of Emigrants and define the area to which the authority of a Registrar so appointed shall extend.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every Registrar shall be a public servant within the meaning of section 21 of the Penal Code (Act XLV of 1860).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Duties and functions of the Registrar</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. Every Registrar shall, in addition to the duties assigned to him by or under this Ordinance, perform such functions as may be assigned to him by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Agents in foreign countries</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The Government may, for the purpose of safeguarding the interest of emigrants and promoting overseas employment, appoint persons to be agents in any place outside Bangladesh and may define their powers and duties.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Delegation of certain authority</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Government may authorise any authority subordinate to it to-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        promote emigration of citizens;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        contract and regulate such emigration; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        look after the interest and welfare of emigrants at home and abroad.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Regulation for emigration</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) Emigration for overseas employment shall not be lawful from any port or place except from such ports or places as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare to be ports or places from which such emigration is lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No person shall, unless he possesses a valid demand, recruit or attempt to recruit any citizen for overseas employment except in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, emigration of a citizen shall be lawful, if he is in possession of valid travel documents with registration endorsement under sub-section (4) of section 11, and-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        he is in possession of a letter of appointment or a work permit from a foreign employer, or an employment or emigration visa from a foreign Government; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        he has been selected for emigration by a foreign employer through an organisation or authority or by a recruiting agent, recognised by the Government in this behalf or under an agreement or treaty between the Government and a foreign Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Power to prohibit emigration of workers</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) If the Government, having regard to the occupation, profession, vocation or qualification of any person or class of persons is satisfied that emigration of such person or class of persons is not in the public interest, it may, by order, prohibit the emigration of such person or class of persons and thereupon the departure of such person or class of persons otherwise than in accordance with such order shall not be lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding the provisions of sub-section (1), where the Government has reason to believe that sufficient grounds exist for prohibiting emigration of any person or any class of persons to any country, it may, by notification in the official Gazette, declare that emigration of such person or class of persons to that country shall cease to be lawful from a date specified in the notification; and from that date such emigration to that country shall accordingly cease to be lawful.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition of advertisement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) No person or organisation shall, except with the prior permission of the Government or any authority designated, recruit or attempt to recruit a citizen for overseas employment or issue an advertisement or publish any material or hold any interview or examination for such recruitment for the purpose of emigration.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No newspaper shall publish any advertisement for employment abroad unless it is satisfied that the same is intended to be issued with the Government approval or clearance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Grant of Licence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) Whoever desires to engage, or to recruit, or to assist, any person to emigrate shall apply to the Government, for licence at such time and in such manner, and shall, with his application, furnish such information and documents and pay such security and fee as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) On receiving an application under sub-section (1), the Government may, after such enquiry regarding the character, antecedents and solvency of the applicant as it may consider</p><p style="text-align: justify;">necessary, grant the licence applied for on such terms and conditions, if any, as may be prescribed, or reject the application for licence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The decision of the Government under sub-section (2), shall be final and shall not be questioned in any Court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A licence under this section may be issued in favour of a citizen or in favour of a corporation, company, partnership firm or any other entity, if-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        in the case of corporation or company, at least sixty per cent of the stock of the corporation or the company, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        in the case of a partnership firm or any other entity, at least sixty per cent of the capital or proprietary right of the firm or the entity, is owned or controlled by Bangladeshi citizens.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Appearance of emigrants before the Registrar, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) Before any person departs from Bangladesh, the person by whom he has been engaged or assisted shall appear in person or by his duly authorised agent before the Registrar and furnish such information regarding terms of his engagement or contract, and such other matters concerning his selection as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If the person departing from Bangladesh is directly appointed or recruited by a foreign Government or organisation or agency or by other foreign employers, such person shall furnish required information to the Registrar.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) If the Registrar is satisfied that the terms of agreement under which a person has been engaged or assisted are in conformity with the terms on the basis of which the licence to recruit was granted, he shall register in a book to be kept for the purpose such particulars concerning the person engaged or assisted and his dependants, if any, and the person engaging or assisting him in such form as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Registration of persons departing Bangladesh shall be endorsed on their passports by the Registrar.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Registration of emigrants residing abroad</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. An emigrant residing abroad and who has not been registered under this Ordinance shall get himself registered with such Labour Attaché or, in his absence, with any such other officer as may be specified by the Government in this behalf and such registration shall be reported to the Registrar.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Non-transferability of licence or authority</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) No licence shall be used, directly or indirectly, by any person other than the person in whose favour it was issued or at any place other than the place mentioned in the licence nor shall the licence be transferred, conveyed or assigned to any person or entity.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) No transfer of the business address or designation of any agent or representative mentioned in the licence shall be made without prior approval of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Cancellation, suspension, forfeiture of security, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) If, at any time during the pendency of a licence, the Government is satisfied, after making such enquiry as it may deem necessary, that the licensee has been guilty of misconduct or that his conduct or performance as a licensee has been unsatisfactory or that he has violated any of the provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder or the prescribed Code of Conduct, it may, after giving the licensee an opportunity of being heard, by order in writing, cancel the licence or suspend it for a period to be specified in the order and may also forfeit the security furnished by him under section 10 in full or in part.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The security money forfeited under sub-section (1) may be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        paid to an affected person, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        utilised for repatriating of any stranded person in foreign country or for such other purpose as the Government may deem appropriate in the public interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) On expiry of the period for which the licence is granted or on the intimation by the licensee that he does not intend to continue to act as a recruiting agent and on being satisfied that no ground for forfeiting the security in whole or in part exists, the Government may order the refund of the security or part thereof to the person by whom it was furnished or to his authorised representative.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to withdraw licence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Ordinance, if, at any time, the Government is satisfied that it is necessary in the public interest to discontinue the practice of granting licence to recruiting agents, it may, by notification in the official Gazette, withdraw all licences granted under section 10.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Decision under sections 14 and 15 to be final</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The decisions of the Government under sections 14 and 15 shall be final and shall not be questioned in any Court of law.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Inspection, etc, to ensure compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance</p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. The Government may, for the enforcement of the provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder, appoint such officers as it may deem fit and an officer so appointed may-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        enter into any office or premise maintained or used by any person or entity in connection with the recruitment of emigrants for overseas employment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        require and enforce the production of any books of accounts and records maintained by such person or entity and inspect such books of accounts and records; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        examine such person or entity and obtain from him or it statement in writing in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to search and detain vessels</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. All the powers for the time being conferred by law on officers of customs with regard to the searching and detention of vessels may be exercised for the prevention of offences under this Ordinance by any such officer or by any officer authorised by the Government in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for all or any of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        powers and duties of officers appointed by the Government under the Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the licensing, supervision and control of persons engaged in recruiting persons for overseas employment or causing or assisting persons to emigrate and in the conveyance and accommodation of emigrants, and the prohibition of unlicensed persons from being so engaged;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        the establishment, supervision and regulation of any place of accommodation provided for emigrants and for their medical care while resident there;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        the forms to be maintained and the returns to be submitted by persons licensed in accordance with the rules made under clause (b);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        the manner of inspection of premises, books of accounts and records of any person or entity connected with recruitment of emigrants for overseas employment;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         the information to be furnished by recruiting agents to emigrants and the language in which such information is to be furnished;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        appearance of emigrants before the Registrar and furnishing information under section 11;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        fees to be paid by a recruiting agent to the Registrar for each emigrant departing Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         setting up training, orientation and briefing centres to guide and advise intending emigrants and their dependants proceeding abroad;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         recall and repatriation, in the public interest, of an emigrant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)        measures to be adopted for the welfare of emigrants and their dependants;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(l)         disposal of complaints against recruiting agents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       formation of an association of recruiting agents and framing of Code of Conduct to be observed by recruiting agents;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n)        service charge to be paid to a recruiting agent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(o)        depositing of fees and securities by a recruiting agent;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(p)        procedure for sending of emigrants by persons possessing secured contract or sub-contract for the purpose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(q)        the security, well-being and protection of emigrants; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(r)        fees receivable from persons recruited and going abroad for employment.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Unlawful emigration</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) Whoever, except in conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance and the rules made thereunder, emigrates or attempts to emigrate or departs or attempts to depart shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year simple imprisonment or with fine not exceeding Taka five thousand or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Whoever, except in conformity with the provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        makes or attempts to make, any agreement with any person purporting to bind that person, or any other person, to emigrate, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        causes or assists, or attempts to cause or assist any person to emigrate or depart or to attempt to emigrate or depart or to leave any place for the purpose of emigrating or departing, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        causes any person engaged, assisted or recruited by him, after grant of the licence under section 10 to depart without appearing before the Registrar as required under section 11, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        furnishes or publishes information or notice or document in relation to recruitment for employment abroad, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        substitutes or alters any employment contract approved and verified by the Registrar, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         withholds or denies travel documents from a prospective emigrant for monetary or financial consideration other than those authorised under this Ordinance,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) When in the course of any proceeding in connection with emigration in which a recruiting agent or a person or an</p><p style="text-align: justify;">organisation is concerned, a breach of the provisions of this Ordinance or the rules made thereunder is committed, such agent or, as the case may be, person or organisation shall be liable to the punishment provided by sub-section (2), unless he proves that he was not responsible for and could not have prevented the commission of the breach.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A person who recruits a citizen or holds an interview or examination or issues an advertisement for such recruitment in contravention of the provisions of section 9 shall be liable to the punishment provided by sub-section (2).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fraudulently inducing to emigrate</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. Whoever, by means of intoxication, coercion or fraud, causes or induces, or attempts to cause or induce, any person to emigrate, or enter into an agreement to emigrate, or leave any place with a view to emigrating, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>False representation of Government authority</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. Whoever falsely represents that any emigrant is required by the Government or is to be engaged on behalf of the Government, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extent to five years, or with fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Receiving money, etc, for providing foreign employment</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">23. Whoever for providing or securing, or on the pretext of providing or securing, to or for any person, employment in any country beyond the limits of Bangladesh-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        being a recruiting agent, charges any fee in addition to the prescribed amount;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        not being a recruiting agent, demands or receives or attempts to receive, for himself or for any other person any money or other valuable thing;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for contravention of agreement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">24. Whoever contravenes the terms of the agreement with his foreign employer by abandoning his employment or otherwise, shall, after the repatriation to Bangladesh, be punishable with fine which may extend to five thousand Taka.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Recovery of expenditure for repatriation, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">25. (1) The amount of expenditure, if any, incurred by the Government for repatriation to Bangladesh of a person who is convicted of an offence punishable under sub-section (1) of section 20 or section 24, shall be recoverable from such person in accordance with the provisions of the Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913 (Ben. Act III of 1913).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may recover the amount involved in an offence under section 21 in accordance with the provisions of the Public Demands Recovery Act, 1913 (Ben. Act III of 1913) and the amount so recovered shall be paid to the person who had paid it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Special Courts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">26. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, establish as many special Courts as it considers necessary for trial of offences under this Ordinance and, where it establishes more than one special Court, shall specify in the notification the headquarters of each special Court and the territorial limits within which it shall exercise jurisdiction under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A special Court shall consist of a person who is the Chairman of a Labour Court established under the Industrial Relations Ordinance, 1969 (XXIII of 1969).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A special Court shall take cognizance of, and have jurisdiction to try, an offence punishable under this Ordinance only upon a complaint in writing made by such person as the Government may, by a general or special order, authorise in this behalf.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A special Court trying an offence under this Ordinance shall try such offence summarily and in trying such offences, such special Court shall follow the procedure laid down in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (Act V of 1898) for summary trial.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">27. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall lie against the Government, Registrar or any person for anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Ordinance not to apply to certain persons</p><p style="text-align: justify;">28. This Ordinance shall not apply to the departure of a person-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        who is not a citizen of Bangladesh, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        who is in the service of the Republic or of a local authority and is proceeding on duty, or on training, or leave, or for employment with any international organisation, with the permission of the Government, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        who is engaged as a member of the crew on board a foreign-going vessel, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        who is a dependent of a citizen already resident or employed in a foreign country and is on a temporary visit to Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal and savings</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">29. (1) The Emigration Act, 1922 (VII of 1922), shall stand repealed in relation to any provision in respect of which this Ordinance comes into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Notwithstanding such repeal,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        anything done or any action taken or any rule made or any notification issued or any proceeding commenced under the provisions of the said Act, shall, in so far as it is not inconsistent with the provisions of this Ordinance, be deemed to have been done, taken, made, issued or commenced, as the case may be, under the corresponding provision of this Ordinance; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        all cases pending before any Court immediately before the commencement of this Ordinance shall be tried and disposed of by such Court, and all matters in connection with such cases shall be regulated in accordance with the provisions of the said Act, as if the said Act had not been repealed by this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
638	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE FAMILY COURTS ORDINANCE, 1985</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE FAMILY COURTS ORDINANCE, 1985</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XVIII OF 1985).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[30th March, 1985]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the establishment of Family Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the establishment of Family Courts and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title, extent and commencement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Family Courts Ordinance, 1985.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It extends to the whole of Bangladesh except the districts of Rangamati Hill Tract, Bandarban Hill Tract and Khagrachari Hill Tract.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (1) In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Code” means the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (V of 1908);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Family Court” means a Family Court established under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Words and expressions used in this Ordinance, but not defined, shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in the Code.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Ordinance to override other laws</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. The provisions of this Ordinance shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Establishment of Family Courts</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) There shall be as many Family Courts as there are Courts of 1[ Assistant Judges].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All Courts of 2[ Assistant Judges] shall be Family Courts for the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All 3[ Assistant Judges] shall be the Judges of Family Courts.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Jurisdiction of Family Courts</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. Subject to the provisions of the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961 (VIII of 1961), a Family Court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to entertain, try and dispose of any suit relating to, or arising out of, all or any of the following matters, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) dissolution of marriage;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) restitution of conjugal rights;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) dower;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) maintenance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) guardianship and custody of children.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Institution of suit</p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. (1) Every suit under this Ordinance shall be instituted by the presentation of a plaint to the Family Court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the cause of action has wholly or partly arisen; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the parties reside or last resided together:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that in suits for dissolution of marriage, dower or maintenance, the Court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the wife ordinarily resides shall also have jurisdiction.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where a plaint is presented to a Court not having jurisdiction,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the plaint shall be returned to be presented to the Court to which it should have been presented;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the Court returning the plaint shall endorse thereon the date of its presentation to it and its return, the name of the party presenting it and a brief statement of the reasons therefore.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The plaint shall contain all material facts relating to the dispute and shall contain a schedule giving the names and addresses of the witnesses intended to be produced in support of the plaint 4[ * * * ]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the plaintiff may, with the permission of the Court, call any witness at any later stage, if the Court considers such evidence expedient in the interest of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The plaint shall also contain the following particulars, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the name of the Court in which the suit is brought;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the name, description and place of residence of the plaintiff;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) the name, description and place of residence of the defendant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) where the plaintiff or the defendant is a minor or a person of unsound mind, a statement to that effect;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) the facts constituting the cause of action and the place where, and the date when, it arose;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) the facts showing that the Court has jurisdiction;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) the relief which the plaintiff claims.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) Where a plaintiff relies upon a document in his possession or power as evidence in support of his claim, he shall produce it in the Court when the plaint is presented and shall at the same time deliver the document or a true or photostat copy thereof to be filed with the plaint 5[ and shall also enter such documents in a list to be added or annexed to the plaint].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Where the plaintiff relies upon a document not in his possession or power as evidence in support of his claim, he shall enter such document in a list to be added or annexed to the plaint and state in whose possession or power it is.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6[ (7) The plaint shall be accompanied by twice as many true copies thereof, including the schedule, and the lists of documents referred to in sub-sections (5) and (6) as there are defendants in the suit for service upon such defendants.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7[ (8) The plaint shall be rejected on the following grounds:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        where it is not accompanied by true copies of plaint including the schedule and the lists of documents required under sub-section (7);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) where the cost of service of summons and postal charges for notice required to be paid under section 7(5) are not paid;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) where the fees required to be paid at the time of presentation of the plaint under section 22 are not paid.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(9) A document which ought to be produced in Court by the plaintiff where the plaint is presented, or to be entered in the list to be added or annexed to the plaint, and which is not produced or entered accordingly, shall not, without the leave of the Court, be received in evidence on his behalf at the hearing of the suit:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Court shall not grant such leave save in exceptional circumstances.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Issue of summons and notice</p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) When a plaint is presented to a Family Court, it shall-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) fix a date ordinarily of not more than thirty days for the appearance of the defendant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        issue summons to the defendant to appear and answer the claim on the date specified therein;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        send to the defendant, by registered post with acknowledgement due, a notice of the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Every summons issued and notice sent under sub-section (1) shall be accompanied by a copy of the plaint 8[ and copies of the list of documents referred to in sections 6(5) and 6(6)].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A summons issued under sub-section (1)(b) shall be served in the manner provided in rules 9, 10, 11, 16, 17, 18, 19, 19A, 9[ 20], 21, 23, 24, 26, 27, 28 and 29 of Order V of the Code; and a summons so served shall be deemed to be due service thereof on the defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) A notice sent under sub-section (1)(c) shall be deemed to be duly served on the defendant when the acknowledgement purporting to be signed by the defendant is received by the Court or the postal article containing the notice is received back by the Court with an endorsement purporting to have been made by a postal employee to the effect that the defendant had refused to take delivery of the postal article containing the notice when tendered to him:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where the notice was properly addressed, prepaid and duly sent by registered post with acknowledgement due, it may be deemed to be duly served on the defendant after the expiry of thirty days from the date of posting of the notice notwithstanding the fact that the acknowledgement having been lost or mislead or for any other reason has not been received by the Court within that period.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The cost of service of summons issued under sub-section (1)(b), which shall be equal to the cost of service of similar summons under the Code, and the postal charges for notice sent under sub-section (1)(c) shall be paid by the plaintiff at the time of presentation of the plaint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Written statement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) On the date fixed for the appearance of the defendant, the plaintiff and the defendant shall appear before the Family Court and the defendant shall present a written statement of his defence 10[ :</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Court may, on the prayer of the defendant and for good cause shown, fix another date not beyond twenty-one days for the presentation of the written statement of his defence.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The written statement shall contain a schedule giving the names and addresses of the witnesses intended to be produced in support of the defence 11[ * * * ]:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the defendant may, with the permission of the Court, call any witness at any later stage, if the Court considers such evidence expedient in the interest of justice.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Where the defendant relies upon a document in his possession or power as evidence in support of his defence, he shall produce it in the Court when the written statement is presented and shall at the same time deliver the document or a</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">true or photostat copy thereof to be filed with the written statement 12[ and shall also enter such documents in a list to be added or annexed to the written statement].</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where the defendant relies upon a document not in his possession or power as evidence in support of his written statement, he shall enter such document in a list to be added or annexed to the written statement and state in whose possession or power it is.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13[ (5) The written statement shall be accompanied by twice as many true copies thereof, including the schedule, and the lists of documents referred to in sub-sections (3) and (4), as there are plaintiffs in the suit.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) Copies of the written statement, including the schedule, the documents and the list of documents referred to in sub-section (5) shall be given to the plaintiff, his agent or advocate present in the Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14[ (7) A document which ought to be produced in Court by the defendant when the written statement is presented, or to be entered in the list to be added or annexed to the written statement, and which is not produced or entered accordingly shall not, without the leave of the Court, be received in evidence on his behalf at the hearing of the suit:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Court shall not grant such leave save in exceptional circumstances.]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Consequence of non-appearance of the parties</p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) Where on the day fixed for the appearance of the defendant, neither party appears when the suit is called on for hearing, the Court may dismiss the suit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where the plaintiff appears and the defendant does not appear when the suit is called on for hearing, then-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        if it is proved that the summons or notice was duly served on the defendant, the Court may proceed ex parte;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) if it is not proved that the summons or notice was duly served on the defendant, the Court shall direct a fresh summons and notice to be issued and served on the defendant;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) if it is proved that the summons or notice was served on the defendant, but not in sufficient time to enable him to appear and answer on the day fixed for his appearance, the Court shall postpone the hearing of the suit to a future day 15[ not exceeding twenty-one days] to be fixed by the Court, and shall give notice of such day to the defendant.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Where a Court has adjourned hearing of the suit ex parte, and the defendant, at or before such hearing, appears and assigns good cause for his previous non-appearance, he may, on such terms as the Court thinks fit, be heard in answer to the suit as if he had appeared on the day fixed for his appearance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) Where the defendant appears and the plaintiff does not appear when the suit is called on for hearing, the Court shall dismiss the suit, unless the defendant admits the claim or part thereof, in which case the Court shall pass a decree against the defendant upon such admission, and, where part only of the claim has been admitted,
