(1) The Director shall have access to any place of deposit of public records and shall have the power to examine such records with a view to listing or collecting information therefrom or to taking such steps as are necessary for their transfer to the National Archives for permanent preservation.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall be the duty of the responsible officer of any public office or any other person for the time being having custody of any public records-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to afford the Director or any other officer authorised by him in writing all facilities for the examination and selection of such public records for permanent preservation and for the transfer of such records to the National Archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        to keep in safe custody in such office any class or description of public records selected by the Director or by such other officer pending the transfer of such records to the National Archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        to perform such duties in connection with selection and listing of such public records in his custody for transfer to the National Archives as may be required by the Director; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        to transfer such records, being records not less than twenty five years old, as are required by the Director to be transferred to the National Archives for permanent preservation:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the transfer of any public records to the National Archives may be temporarily deferred and such records retained in the office of origin for administrative or other purposes for such period as may be agreed upon by the responsible officer of such office and the Director, and in every such case a list of records so retained shall be transferred to the Director by the responsible officer:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided further that the responsible officer transferring any public records which he may consider to be of a confidential or secret nature or which contain any other information which should not be divulged to the public may specify conditions subject to which such records shall be kept in the National Archives or shall be made available for public inspection, and it shall be the duty of the Director to comply with such conditions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Destruction of records</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. The Director may authorise destruction of any specified classes of public records which-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        by reason of their number, kind or routine nature do not, in his opinion, possess any enduring value for preservation as public archives, and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        are not required for reference purposes in any public office after action on them is completed or after expiration of such period of years from the date on which action on them is completed as may be agreed upon between the Director and the administrative head of that public office.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Access of public to public records</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) Subject to the conditions under which any public records are made available or are deposited in the National Archives, public archives shall be made available to the public for the purpose of reference or research which are of more than thirty years old.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All applications for the inspection of records shall be addressed to the Director.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Procedure relating to documents where public office is to be closed down</p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. Where any public office is due to be closed down or wound up, the responsible officer of such public office shall transfer to the Director a complete list of all public records in that office and shall make arrangements to deposit in the National Archives such records as the Director may select or require for permanent preservation in the National Archives.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Records of Commissions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. It shall be the duty of the Secretary of any Commission of Inquiry appointed under the Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1956 (VI of 1956), or any Committee of Inquiry appointed by the Government to deposit all records relating to such Commission or Committee, as the case may be, at the National Archives within three months of the rendering of the final report of such Commission or Committee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Documents and manuscripts in private possession</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) Any private individual or the chief executive officer of any institution in possession of any manuscript or document over seventy-five years old, being a manuscript or document of historical, cultural or literary value, may notify the Director of the existence of such document or manuscript.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Such individual or executive officer shall, afford the Director all facilities to inspect such manuscript or document.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Such individual or executive officer shall, if agreed upon by the Director, deposit at the National Archives such manuscript or document either on a permanent or temporary basis and may specify the conditions subject to which such manuscript or document shall be made available for public inspection or extracts or copies therefrom shall be taken for publication or for any other purpose.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Prohibition of export of certain documents and manuscripts from Bangladesh</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) No person shall, except on the authority of a written permission issued in that behalf by the Director, export out of Bangladesh any public record, document or manuscript or any other printed matter, being a public record, document, manuscript or printed matter which is over seventy-five years old and which is of historical or cultural or literary value.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Director may refuse to issue a written permission if he considers that such record, document or manuscript is of such historical, cultural or literary value that its export will not be in the national interest.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Any person aggrieved by the refusal of the Director to issue any written permit under this provision may appeal against such refusal to the Government within fourteen days of the communication of such refusal and the decision of the Government thereon shall be final and conclusive.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Official seal</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. (1) There shall be an official seal of the National Archives of a design approved by the Government and such seal shall be judicially noticed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The seal of the National Archives shall be kept in the custody of the Director and may be used by him or any officer authorised by him in that behalf for the purpose of National Archives.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Authentication of copies and extracts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. A copy of, or an extract from, any public archives or any private document or manuscript deposited in the National Archives purporting to be duly certified as true and authenticated by the Director or any other officer authorised by him in writing for the purpose and having impressed thereon the official seal of the National Archives, shall be admissible in evidence in any proceeding in any Court in like manner and to the like extent as the original document or manuscript would have been admissible.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Deposit in the National Archives of public and private records received for permanent preservation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. All public and private records received for permanent preservation by the Director shall be deposited in the repositories of the National Archives.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Temporary transfer of records from National Archives</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. Subject to the provisions of this section, no public archives shall be removed from the National Archives to any other place for any purposes whatsoever:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that where any public office which has transferred to the National Archives any record, document, manuscript or other thing requires the same for inspection, such record, manuscript, document or thing may be forwarded to such office by the Director for inspection and that office shall return the same within such period as may be specified by the Director.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Annual report</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. The Chairman shall submit an annual report on the activities of the Advisory Council to the Government and the Government, after examining the report, may issue such order or direction as it deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalties</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">21. Any person who knowingly defaces, marks on, mutilates or causes damage to any record, manuscript or document deposited in the National Archives or who destroys any public record otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this Ordinance or any rules made thereunder or who contravenes any provision of this Ordinance or any rules made thereunder shall be punishable with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to fifteen days, or with fine which may extend to five hundred Taka, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">22. (1) The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing power, such rules may provide for-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) selection of public records and private document and manuscripts for permanent preservation, their transfer to and deposit in the National Archives and the measures to be taken for their effective preservation in the National Archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) temporary deposit of any specified class or description of public records at places other than the National Archives pending their transfer to the National Archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) care and custody of public records in Government Departments and other institutions;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) public access to the public archives and the terms and conditions subject to which public archives of any specified class or description of public archives are open to inspection by the members of the public;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)  prohibition or restriction of the disclosure of information obtained by the public from public archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)   maintenance of secrecy by officers of the National Archives in respect of any class or description of public archives in respect of which secrecy is required to be maintained by or under any law;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) purchase from private individuals or organisations of manuscripts, documents and other printed matter of historical or cultural or literary value for permanent preservation in the National Archives;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)  destruction of valueless records and documents in public offices and preparation of schedules therefore; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)  holding of exhibitions and expositions of public archives.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
666	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE NATIONAL CURRICULUM AND TEXT-BOOK BOARD ORDINANCE 1983   </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE NATIONAL CURRICULUM AND TEXT-BOOK BOARD ORDINANCE 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. LVII OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[2nd October, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the establishment of a National Curriculum and Text Book Board.WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the establishment of a National Curriculum and Text Book Board and for matters connected therewith;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the National Curriculum and Text-Book Board Ordinance, 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Board” means the National Curriculum and Text Book Board established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “member” means a member of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        “prescribed” means prescribed by regulations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        “school” means any educational institution excluding a Madrasah which imparts education up to class XII, whether such institution is recognised or approved under any law or by any authority or not;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         “text book” means a text book for any class of any school.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Establishment of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, establish a Board to be called the National Curriculum and Text Book Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall be a body corporate, having perpetual succession and a common seal, with powers, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance and the regulations, to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Board shall, in the discharge of its functions, be guided by such directives and instructions as the Government may, from time to time, give.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Head Office, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The head office of the Board shall be situated at Dhaka.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board may, with the prior approval of the Government, open branch offices at any place within Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Composition of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The Board shall consist of a Chairman and 1[ four] other members to be appointed by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Chairman and other members shall be full time officers and shall hold office on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Chairman</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Chairman shall be the chief executive of the Board and shall perform such functions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Secretary</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) There shall be a Secretary to the Board who shall be appointed by the Government on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Secretary shall perform such functions as the Board may decide.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Meetings of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) The meetings of the Board shall be held at such times and places and in such manner as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, until so prescribed, such meetings shall be held at such times and places as may be determined by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To constitute a quorum at a meeting of the Board, not less than two members shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All meetings of the Board shall be presided over by the Chairman and, in his absence, by a member chosen by the members present from amongst themselves.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) At a meeting of the Board, each member shall have one vote, and, in the event of an equality of votes, the Chairman shall have a second or casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) No act or proceedings of the Board shall be invalid or be called in question merely on the ground of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Functions of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The functions of the Board shall be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to examine curricula and syllabi of schools and suggest revision thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to pre test and evaluate the effectiveness of the curricula, syllabi and text books of schools;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to arrange for the preparation, of the manuscripts of the text books;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) to arrange for the publication, distribution and sale of text books;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to approve of the text books, prize books, library and reference books;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) to encourage scientific, literary and cultural works by providing grants and donations;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) to donate books to the poor and deserving students;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h) to do such other acts and things as may be assigned to it by the Government from time to time.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of committees</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) There shall be the following committees of the Board, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) Syllabus Committee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) Text Book Committee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Each committee shall consist of such number of members as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The members of the committees shall be appointed by the Government on the recommendation of the Board from among the following persons, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) subject specialists;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) class room teachers;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) renowned intellectuals;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) officers of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The members of the committees shall hold office on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Board may appoint such other committees as it deems necessary to assist it in the performance of its functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of officers, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. The Board may appoint such officers and other employees as it considers necessary for the performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Board Fund</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. (1) The Board shall have its own Fund which shall be utilized by it to meet the charges in connection with its functions under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Fund shall consist of-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) grants made by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) loans obtained from the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) loans raised in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) grants received from foreign countries or organisations with the prior approval of the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) income from investments and properties;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) fees and royalties, if any, collected by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All moneys of the Board shall be kept in any scheduled bank.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Budget</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. The Board shall, by such date in each year as may be directed by the Government, prepare a budget and submit it to the Government for approval.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Accounts and audit</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Board shall maintain its accounts in such manner and form as the Government may, in consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor General of Bangladesh (hereinafter referred to as the Auditor General), specify.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts of the Board shall be audited by the Auditor General in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of audit under sub section (2), the Auditor-General or any person authorised by him in that behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash, securities, stores and other property held and controlled by the Board and may examine the Chairman or any member, officer or employee of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Auditor General shall submit his audit report to the Government and forward a copy thereof to the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Board shall submit its comments on the audit report to the Government and shall take steps as may be necessary to remedy any defects or irregularities pointed out in the audit report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Text books for schools</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. (1) No book which has not been approved as a text book by the Board or which has not been prepared and published by it shall be prescribed as a text book in any school:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, exempt any school or class of schools from the operation of this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The copyright of all text books and other books published by the Board shall vest in the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Powers of Government to call for information</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The Government may call for any information or report on any matter of the Board from the Chairman and it shall be the duty of the Chairman to furnish such information or report to the Government within a reasonable time or within the time specified by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Information, report, etc, from the publishers</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Board may require any printer, publisher, distributor, whole-seller or retailer of any text¬-book to furnish any information, return or report in respect of such text book.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) If any printer, publisher, distributor, whole seller or retailer when required to furnish any information, return or report under sub section (1), fails to furnish such information, return or report or furnishes any information, return or report which is false in any material particular and which he knows or has reasonable cause to believe to be false or does not believe to be true, he shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years or with fine, or with both.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Delegation of powers</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">18. The Board may, by general or special order in writing, direct that such of its powers shall, in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercisable also by the Chairman or by such other member as may be so specified.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">19. (1) The Board may, with the previous approval of the Government, make regulations for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All regulations made under this section shall be published in the official Gazette and shall come into force on such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal and savings</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">20. (1) On the establishment of the Board, the School Text Book Act, 1954 (E. B. Act XIV of 1954), shall stand repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Upon the repeal under sub section (1),-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) the Bangladesh School Text Book Board, hereinafter referred to as the dissolved Board, shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) the National Curriculum Development Centre, hereinafter referred to as the dissolved Centre, shall, notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any rule, regulation or by-law, or in any contract or agreement, stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) all assets, rights, powers, authorities, privileges and all properties, movable and immovable, including lands, buildings, works, machineries, licences, permits, cash, bank balance, funds, investments of the dissolved Board and of the dissolved Centre and all other rights and interests in and arising out of such properties shall stand transferred to, and vest in the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) all debts, obligations and liabilities incurred, all contracts entered into and all matters and things engaged to be done by, with or for, the dissolved Board and the dissolved Centre immediately before such repeal shall be deemed to have been incurred, entered into, or engaged to be done by, with or for, the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) all commissions, fees and royalties payable to the dissolved Board or the dissolved Centre shall be payable to the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the dissolved Board or dissolved Centre before such repeal shall be deemed to be suits and proceedings by or against the Board and shall be proceeded or otherwise dealt with accordingly;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) every officer and other employee of the dissolved Board and the dissolved Centre shall stand transferred to the Board and shall serve the Board on the same terms and conditions as were applicable to them immediately before their transfer and shall continue to do so unless and until the employment in the Board is terminated or until his terms and conditions of service are altered by the Board with the prior approval of the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Government may, for the purpose of removing any difficulty in relation to the transfer or other matters specified in this section, make such order as it considers expedient and any such order shall be deemed to be, and given effect to as, part of the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1 The word “four” was substituted for the word “three” by section 5 of The National Curriculum and Text-Book Board (Amendment) Act, 2010 (Act No. 4 of 2010).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p>ORDINANCE NO. LVII OF 1983)                      </div></div>
667	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE NAZRUL INSTITUTE ORDINANCE 1984</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE NAZRUL INSTITUTE ORDINANCE 1984</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO XXXIX OF 1984).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[12th June, 1984]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the establishment of the Nazrul Institute. WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the establishment of the Nazrul Institute and for matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Commencement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Nazrul Institute Ordinance 1984.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Board” means the Board of Trustees of the Institute;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Institute;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Institute;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “Institute” means the Nazrul Institute established under section 3;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “poet” means the poet Kazi Nazrul Islam;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) “prescribed” means prescribed by rules or regulations made under this Ordinance; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) “trustee” means a member of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Establishment of the Institute</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) There shall be an Institute to be called the Nazrul Institute for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Institute shall be a body corporate, having perpetual succession and a common seal, with power to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>General direction</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Subject to the rules and regulations made under this Ordinance, the general direction and administration of the affairs of the Institute shall vest in a Board of Trustees which may exercise all powers and do all acts or things which may be exercised or done by the Institute.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. (1) The Board shall consist of the following trustees, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) a Chairman to be appointed by the Government from among eminent persons interested in Nazrul sangeet and literature;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) one representative of the Cultural Affairs Division to be nominated by that Division;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) four persons to be nominated by the Government from among persons interested in literary and musical works of the poet; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) Executive Director of the Institute, who shall also be the Member-Secretary of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) A trustee nominated under sub-section (1)(c) shall hold office for a period of three years from the date of his nominations and shall be eligible for re-nomination.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) A trustee nominated under sub-section (1)(c) may resign his office by a notice in writing addressed to the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Functions of the Institute</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The function of the Institute shall be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        to promote the study of the works of the poet;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)       to collect the poet's songs and other works from home and abroad and to compile, preserve and publish them;(c)to make necessary arrangement for research on, and publication of, the literature of the poet and for publicity thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        to organise conferences, lectures, debates and seminars on matters relating to contributions of the poet on sangeet, literature and in other fields;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        to establish library of books, records, tapes and other preservative ensemble relating to Nazrul sangeet and literature;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)     to prepare musical notation for propagation of Nazrul sangeet in their true spirit, style and system and to supervise their presentation in acceptable standard in gramophone records, commercial tapes, films and books of published notation in Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)        to provide for proper training in Nazrul sangeet and recitation of the Nazrul poems;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        to award prizes and rewards to authors who, in the opinion of the Institute, have made significant contributions in the field of research on the works of the poet;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         to do such other acts and things as may be considered necessary for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Meetings of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. (1) The meetings of the Board shall be held at such time and places and in such manner as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, until so prescribed, such meetings shall be held at such time and places as may be determined by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To constitute a quorum at a meeting of the Board, not less than three trustees shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All meetings of the Board shall be presided over by the Chairman and, in his absence, by a trustee authorised in writing by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) At a meeting of the Board, each trustee shall have one vote and, in the event of equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a second or casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid or be called in question merely on the ground of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Executive Director</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) There shall be an Executive Director of the Institute who shall be appointed by the Government on such terms and conditions as may be determined by it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Executive Director shall be a whole time officer and the Chief Executive of the Institute.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Executive Director shall manage the business and fund of the Institute and shall be responsible for the proper execution of the decisions of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Executive Director shall perform such other functions as may be assigned by the Board or as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) If a vacancy occurs in the office of the Executive Director or if the Executive Director is unable to discharge the functions of his office on account of absence, illness or any other cause, the Government shall make such arrangement for discharging the functions of the Executive Director as it may consider expedient.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of the officers, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. The Board may, subject to such general or special order as the Government may give from time to time, appoint such officers and employees as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Delegation of powers</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. The Board may, by general or special order in writing, direct that such of its powers shall, in such circumstances and under such conditions, if any, as may be specified in the order, be exercisable also by the Chairman, a trustee, Executive Director or by such other officer of the Institute as may be so specified  :</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no power to make regulations under section 17 shall be delegated under this section.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Funds of the Institute</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) The funds of the Institute shall comprise-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) grants made by the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) grants from the local authorities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) sale proceeds and royalties accruing from the property owned by the Institute; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) receipt from any other source.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The funds of the Institute shall be kept in a schedule bank approved by the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Budget of the Institute</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Institute shall, by such date in each year as may be specified by the Government, submit to the Government for approval a budget for each financial year showing the estimated receipts and expenditure and the sum which are likely to be required from the Government during that financial year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Audit and Accounts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) The Institute shall maintain its accounts in such manner and form as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts of the Institute shall be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of Bangladesh, hereinafter in this section referred to as the Auditor-General, in such manner as he deems fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) For the purpose of an audit under sub-section (2), the Auditor-General or any person authorised by him in this behalf shall have access to all records, books, documents, cash, securities, stores and other property of the Institute and may examine the Chairman or any other trustee or the Executive Director or any officer or employee of the Institute.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Auditor-General shall, as soon as possible after completion of the audit, send to the Board his audit report and Board shall forward it with its comments thereon to the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) The Institute shall take steps forthwith to remedy any defect or irregularity pointed out in the audit report.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Submission of annual report, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">14. (1) The Institute shall, as soon as possible after the end of every financial year, submit to the Government an annual report on the conduct of its affairs for that year.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may require the Institute to furnish any report, return, statement, estimate, statistics or other information regarding any matter under the control of the Institute and the Institute shall comply with every such requisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Indemnity</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">15. No suit, prosecution or other legal proceedings shall lie against the Board, the Chairman, a trustee, the Executive Director or any officer or employee of the Institute for anything done or intended to be done in good faith under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make rules</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">16. The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, make rules for carrying out the purposes of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">17. (1) The Board may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Ordinance or rules made thereunder, to provide for all matters for which provision is necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) All regulations made under this section shall be published in the official Gazette and shall come into force on such publication.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
668	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">  THE OFF-SHORE ISLANDS DEVELOPMENT BOARD (DISSOLUTION) ORDINANCE, 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE OFF-SHORE ISLANDS DEVELOPMENT BOARD (DISSOLUTION) ORDINANCE, 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXVIII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[21st September, 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to make provision for the dissolution of the Off shore Islands Development Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provision for the dissolution of the Off shore Islands Development Board and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title and commencement</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Off-shore  Islands Development Board (Dissolution) Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2)        It shall come into force on the 1st October,  1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “Divisional Development Board” means any one of the following Boards, namely:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         the Khulna Division Development Board established under the Khulna Division Development Board Ordinance, 1976 (Ord. LXXV of 1976);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        the Rajshahi Division Development Board established under the Rajshahi Division Development Board Ordinance, 1976 (Ord. LXXX of 1976);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iii)       the Dacca Division Development Board established under the Dacca Division Development Board Ordinance, 1976 (Ord. LXXXI of 1976);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(iv)       the Chittagong Division Development Board established under the Chittagong Division Development Board Ordinance, 1976 (Ord. LXXXIX of 1976).</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “undertaking” includes any project, scheme, asset, light, power, authority and privilege and any property movable and immovable including any land, building, work, machinery, cash or bank balance, reserve fund, investment, and any other right and interest in, or arising out of such property and any book of accounts, register, record and any other document of whatever nature relating thereto.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Dissolution of the Board</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3.         (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law, rule, regulation, agreement or contract for the time being in force, on the commencement of this Ordinance,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        the Off shore Islands Development Board established under section 3 of the Off shore Islands Development Board Ordinance, 1977 (Ord. IV of 1977), hereinafter referred to as the said Board, shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        the undertakings of the said Board shall be transferred to such Divisional Development Board as the Government may direct;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        all debts, liabilities and obligations incurred, all contracts entered into and all matters and things engaged to be done by, with or for, the said Board arising out of, or connected with or incidental to, any undertaking before the commencement of this Ordinance shall be deemed to have been incurred, entered into or engaged to be done by, with or for the Divisional Development Board to which the undertaking has been transferred under clause (b);</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        all suits and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said Board arising out of, connected with or incidental to, any undertaking before the commencement of this Ordinance shall be deemed to be suits and other legal proceedings by or against the Divisional Development Board to which the said undertaking has been transferred; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        the Off shore Islands Development Board Ordinance, 1977 (Ord. IV of 1977), shall stand repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
669	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PRIMARY EDUCATION (REPEAL) ORDINANCE 1983   </h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE PRIMARY EDUCATION (REPEAL) ORDINANCE 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XLV OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[4th September, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to repeal the Primary Education Act 1981. WHEREAS it is expedient to repeal the Primary Education Act, 1981 (IV of 1981);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Primary Education (Repeal) Ordinance 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Repeal of Act IV of 1981</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. The Primary Education Act, 1981 (IV of 1981), is hereby repealed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
670	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PUBLIC EMPLOYEES DISCIPLINE (PUNCTUAL ATTENDANCE) ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE PUBLIC EMPLOYEES DISCIPLINE (PUNCTUAL ATTENDANCE) ORDINANCE 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XXXIV OF 1982)</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[14th September 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provisions to ensure discipline and punctuality among the public employees;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982 and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance shall be called the Public Employees Discipline (Punctual Attendance) Ordinance 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “authority” means the appointing authority or an officer or authority designated by it to exercise the powers of authority under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “public employee” means a person in the service of the Republic or in the employment of any statutory body.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Ordinance to override other laws, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. This Ordinance shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in any law, rules or regulations relating to public employees or in the conditions of service of any public employee.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for absence from work without permission</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. If a public employee without prior permission from his higher authority proceeds on leave or absents himself from work, the authority shall deduct an amount equivalent to his basic pay for one day for each day of absence.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for leaving office without permission</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. If a public employee without prior permission from his higher authority leaves his office during the office hours, the authority shall deduct an amount equivalent to his basic pay for one day for each such occasion.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for late attendance</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. If a public employee comes late to his office, the authority shall deduct an amount equivalent to his basic pay for one day for each two days of late attendance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Penalty for repeated offence</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. If a public employee is found to have committed within a period of thirty days, any of the offences mentioned in section 4 or 5 or 6 for more than once, the authority may deduct an additional amount equivalent to his basic pay for seven days.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Representation</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. In the event of any deduction from the pay of any public employee being ordered under section 4 or 5 or 6 or 7, the public employee concerned may represent within forty eight hours to the authority for a revision of the order, whereupon the authority after such hearing as he thinks fit, may revise, set aside or confirm his order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Consultation with Public Service Commission not necessary</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. No consultation with the Public Service Commission shall be necessary on any matter under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Court’s jurisdiction barred</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. No proceeding or order under this Ordinance shall be called in question in any Court.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
671	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE PUBLIC SERVANTS (DISMISSAL ON CONVICTION) ORDINANCE, 1985</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">THE PUBLIC SERVANTS (DISMISSAL ON CONVICTION) ORDINANCE, 1985</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. V OF 1985).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[3rd February, 1985]</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for dismissal of a public servant on his conviction of certain criminal offences.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the dismissal of a public servant on his conviction of certain criminal offences;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the President is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Short title</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Public Servants (Dismissal on Conviction) Ordinance, 1985.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Definitions</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “public servant” means a person in the service of the Republic and includes a chairman, vice-chairman, director, managing director, trustee, member, commissioner, teacher, officer or other employee of any local authority, statutory corporation, including a university, or any other body, authority or organisation constituted or established by the Government or by or under any law, but does not include any person who-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) is a member of any defence service; or</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii)        holds any office which is filled by election under any law; and</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “Schedule” means the Schedule annexed to this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Dismissal of public servants on conviction</p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any rule, regulation, bye-law, instrument or contract or in any terms and conditions of service, a public servant shall, on his conviction of a criminal offence specified in the Schedule, stand dismissed from service on the date of delivery of the judgment or order convicting him.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Court convicting of public servant of criminal offence specified in the Schedule shall, if the fact of his being a public servant comes to its knowledge in the course of the trial, inform his employer of his conviction immediately after the delivery of the judgment or order.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) If a public servant dismissed under sub-section (1) is acquitted on appeal by a Appellate Court, he shall be re-instated in service, provided he has not already attained the age of superannuation or the post or service concerned has not been abolished.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Exemption, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) Where the President is satisfied that there are extenuating circumstances to exempt any public servant from the application of the provisions of section 3, he may, by order, direct that section 3 shall not apply to that public servant whereupon the public servant shall be deemed not to have been dismissed from service.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) Where an order under sub-section (1) is made by the President, the President or the appointing authority or any authority not subordinate to the appointing authority may make such order in respect of the public servant, other than an order for dismissal, as he or it may deem fit.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Application of other laws, etc</p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The provisions of this Ordinance shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, any other law, rule or regulation for the time being in force relating to the terms and conditions of service of a public servant including disciplinary matters.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">Source : Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p> </div></div>
672	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE SANTOSH ISLAMIC UNIVERSITY (BOARD OF TRUSTEES) ORDINANCE 1983</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE SANTOSH ISLAMIC UNIVERSITY (BOARD OF TRUSTEES) ORDINANCE 1983</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. LXV OF 1983).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[10th November, 1983]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to provide for the constitution of a Board of Trustees for the better administration and development of the Santosh Islamic University.WHEREAS it is expedient to provide for the constitution of a Board of Trustees for the better administration and development of the Santosh Islamic University and for matters ancillary thereto;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March, 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;"></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. This Ordinance may be called the Santosh Islamic University (Board of Trustees) Ordinance 1983.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) “Board” means the Santosh Islamic University Board of Trustees;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) “Chairman” means the Chairman of the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) “prescribed” means prescribed by regulations made under this Ordinance;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “Santosh Islamic University” means the Islamic University at Santosh in the district of Tangail established by Moulana Abdul Hamid Khan Bhasani;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “Trustee” means a Trustee of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Constitution of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">3. (1) As soon as may be after the commencement of this Ordinance, the Government shall, by notification in the official Gazette, constitute a Board of Trustees for the Santosh Islamic University to be called the Santosh Islamic University Board of Trustees.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Board shall be a body corporate having perpetual succession and a common seal with power to acquire, hold and dispose of property, both moveable and immoveable, and shall by the said name sue and be sued.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Composition of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">4. (1) The Board shall consist of nine Trustees to be appointed by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government shall appoint from among the Trustees a Chairman, Vice-Chairman and a Secretary of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The Chairman and the Secretary shall be full-time Trustees and shall hold office on such terms and conditions as the Government may determine.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) The Vice-Chairman and other Trustees shall hold office for a period of three years from the date of their appointment:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that the Government may terminate the appointment of any of these Trustees before the expiration of his term.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) A Trustee may resign his office by writing under his hand addressed to the Government:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that no resignation shall take effect until it has been accepted by the Government.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Functions of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">5. The functions of the Board shall be-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) to administer all properties, moveable and immoveable, of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) to raise and collect funds for the Santosh Islamic University and to invest them;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) to take over the funds and properties of the Santosh Islamic University in the possession and management of its Project Implementation Committees;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)to take over the educational and religious institutions of the Santosh Islamic University including the vocational projects and production units thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) to maintain, supervise and develop the educational and religious institutions of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)to implement the vocational projects of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g)to manage and develop the production units of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)to regulate the conduct and services of the officers and employees of the educational and religious institutions and projects of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i) to prepare master plan for the Santosh Islamic University and to take steps for the implementation of the plan;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)to set up and maintain new educational and religious institutions keeping in view the aims and objects of the Santosh Islamic University;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k)to do such other things ancillary or incidental to any of the aforesaid functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of Committees</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">6. The Board may appoint from among the Trustees such Committee or Committees as it may deem necessary to assist it in the performance of its functions.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Appointment of officers, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">7. The Board may appoint such officers and other employees as it considers necessary for the efficient performance of its functions on such terms and conditions as may be prescribed.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Meetings of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">8. (1) The meetings of the Board shall be held at such times and places and in such manner as may be prescribed:</p><p style="text-align: justify;">Provided that, until so prescribed, such meetings shall be held at such times and places as may be determined by the Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) To constitute a quorum at a meeting of the Board, not less than three Trustees shall be present.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) All meetings of the Board shall be presided over by the Chairman and, in his absence, by the Vice-Chairman.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(4) At a meeting of the Board, each Trustee shall have one vote and, in the event of equality of votes, the Chairman shall have a second or casting vote.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(5) Proceedings of the meetings of the Board shall be recorded and maintained by the Secretary and circulated by him among the Trustees within a month and submitted for confirmation at the next meeting of the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(6) No act or proceedings of the Board shall be invalid or called in question merely on the ground of any vacancy in, or any defect in the constitution of, the Board.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Funds of the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">9. (1) The Board shall have its own fund which shall be utilized by it to meet the charges in connection with its functions under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The funds of the Board shall comprise-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)funds of the Santosh Islamic University, the Santosh Islamic University Project Implementation Committee and the Local Project Committee;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        grants from the Government;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        grants from the local authorities;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)        donations and endowments;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e)        receipts from the institutions maintained by the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f)         receipts from any other source.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(3) The funds of the Board shall be kept in any scheduled bank, and its bank account shall be operated by such Trustee or Trustees as it may specify.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Audit and accounts</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">10. (1) The Board shall keep proper accounts of all moneys received and expended by it.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The accounts of the Board shall be audited by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of Bangladesh.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Submission of reports, etc</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">11. (1) The Board shall submit to the Government an annual report on the conduct of its affairs.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may require the Board to furnish any report, statement or information regarding any matter under the control of the Board, and the Board shall comply with such requisition.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Power to make regulations</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">12. The Board may, with the previous approval of the Government, make regulations to provide for all matters for which provision is necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Transfer of assets, etc, of the Santosh Islamic University to the Board</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">13. (1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, or in any agreement, deed or other instrument, upon the constitution of the Board,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)the Santosh Islamic University Project Implementation Committee and the Local Project Committee of the Santosh Islamic University, hereinafter referred to as the said Committees, shall stand dissolved;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) all assets, rights, powers, authorities and privileges and all properties, moveable and immoveable, cash and bank balances, funds, investments and all other rights and interests in, or arising out of, such properties of the said Committees and also of the Santosh Islamic University shall stand transferred to and vest in the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)all debts, liabilities and obligations of the said Committees and also of the Santosh Islamic University shall stand transferred to the Board;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d)all suits, prosecutions and other legal proceedings instituted by or against the said Committees or the Santosh Islamic University before such constitution shall be deemed to be suits, prosecutions or proceedings by or against the Board and shall be proceeded or otherwise dealt with accordingly.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) The Government may, for the purpose of removing any difficulty in relation to the transfer and other matters specified in sub-section (1), make such orders as it considers expedient, and any such order shall be deemed to be, and given effect to as, part of the provisions of this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Source</strong> :  Ministry of Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs</p> </div></div>
673	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">THE STANDARDS OF WEIGHTS AND MEASURES ORDINANCE 1982</h2>
<div class="entry-content"><div class="entry-content"><p style="text-align: justify;">THE STANDARDS OF WEIGHTS AND MEASURES ORDINANCE 1982</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ORDINANCE NO. XII OF 1982).</p><p style="text-align: justify;">[26th June 1982]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">An Ordinance to establish standards of weights and measures based on metric system and units of measurement.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">WHEREAS it is expedient to make provision for the establishment of standards of weights and measures based on metric system and units of measurement and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereof;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">NOW, THEREFORE, in pursuance of the Proclamation of the 24th March 1982, and in exercise of all powers enabling him in that behalf, the Chief Martial Law Administrator is pleased to make and promulgate the following Ordinance:-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">PART I</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>PRELIMINARY</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>commencement</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (1) This Ordinance may be called the Standards of Weights and Measures Ordinance, 1982.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(2) It shall come into force on such date as the Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint; and different dates may be appointed for different-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a) provisions of this Ordinance,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b) areas,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c) classes of goods,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) classes of undertakings,</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) classes of weights and measures, or</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(f) classes of users of weights and measures, and any reference in any such provision to the commencement of this Ordinance shall be construed as a reference to the coming into force of that provision in such areas, or in respect of such classes of undertakings, goods, weights and measures or users of weights and measures in relation to which this Ordinance has been brought into force.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Definitions</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “authorised person” means a person authorised by the Government to exercise or perform any specific power or duty under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “calibration” means all the operation which are necessary for the purpose of determining the values of the errors of a weight or measure and, if necessary, to determine the other metro logical properties of such weight or measure, and includes the actual fixing of the positions of the gauge marks or scale marks of a weight or measure, or in some cases, of certain principal marks only, in relation to the corresponding values of the quantity to be measured;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation:</strong> Calibration may also be carried out with a view to permitting the use of a weight or measure as a standard;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “commercial weight or measure” means weight or measure purporting to be a standard of weight or measure used in any transaction for trade or commerce;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “commodity in packaged form” means commodity packaged, whether in any bottle, in wrapper or otherwise, in units suitable for sale, whether wholesale or retail;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “dealer”, in relation to any weight or measure, means a person who, or a firm or a family which, carries on directly or otherwise, the business of buying, selling, supplying or distributing any such weight or measures, whether for cash or for deferred payment or for commission, remuneration or other valuable consideration, and includes-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         a commission agent who carries on such business on behalf of any principal;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) an importer sells, supplies, distributes or otherwise delivers any weight or measure to any user, manufacturer, repairer, consumer or any other person, but does not include a manufacturer who sells, supplies, distributes or otherwise delivers any weight or measures to any person or category of persons referred to in this clause;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. In this Ordinance, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context,-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(a)        “authorised person” means a person authorised by the Government to exercise or perform any specific power or duty under this Ordinance.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(b)        “calibration” means all the operation which are necessary for the purpose of determining the values of the errors of a weight or measure and, if necessary, to determine the other metrological properties of such weight or measure, and includes the actual fixing of the positions of the gauge marks or scale marks of a weight or measure, or in some cases, of certain principal marks only, in relation to the corresponding values of the quantity to be measured;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation: </strong>Calibration may also be carried out with a view to permitting the use of a weight or measure as a standard</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(c)        “commercial weight or measure” means weight or measure purporting to be a standard of weight or measure used in any transaction for trade or commerce;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(d) “commodity in packaged form” means commodity packaged, whether in any bottle, in wrapper or otherwise, in units suitable for sale, whether wholesale or retail;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(e) “dealer”, in relation to any weight or measure, means a person who, or a firm or a family which, carries on directly or otherwise, the business of buying, selling, supplying or distributing any such weight or measures, whether for cash or for deferred payment or for commission, remuneration or other valuable consideration, and includes-</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         a commission agent who carries on such business on behalf of any principal;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(ii) an importer sells, supplies, distributes or otherwise delivers any weight or measure to any user, manufacturer, repairer, consumer or any other person, but does not include a manufacturer who sells, supplies, distributes or otherwise delivers any weight or measures to any person or category of persons referred to in this clause;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Explanation</strong>: For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that a manufacturer, who sells, supplies, distributes or otherwise delivers any weight or measure to any person other than a dealer, shall be deemed to be a dealer;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">1. (f) “Director-General” means the Director-General of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution established under the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Ordinance, 1985 (XXXVII of 1985);]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(g) “export”, with its grammatical variations and cognate expressions, means taking out of Bangladesh to a place outside Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(h)        “false package” means any package which does not conform to the provisions of this Ordinance or any rule or order made thereunder in relation to such package;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(i)         “false weight or measure” means any weight or measure which does not conform to the standards established by or under this Ordinance in relation to that weight or measure;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(j)         “General Conference on Weights and Measures” means the Conference General des Poids et Measures established under the Convention de Metre;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(k) “import”, with its grammatical variations and cognate expressions, means bringing into Bangladesh from a place outside Bangladesh;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">2. (l)     “Inspector” means an Inspector appointed under section 14, and shall include an Inspector appointed under section 25 of the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Ordinance, 1985 (XXXVII of 1985);</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(m)       “Institution” means the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution established under the Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution Ordinance, 1985 (XXXVII of 1985);]</p><p style="text-align: justify;">(n) “International Bureau of Weights and Measures” means the Bureau International des Poids et Measures, established under the
